dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A freight truck of late 1950's vintage pulls to the side the road in a small rural town. A handsome, well-built ma gets out of the passenger side and thanks the Driver. THE NEWCOMER carries his coat over his shoulder and a beat-up suitcase; he's got a jut jaw and a modified pompadour, hi shirtsleeves are rolled all the way up past his biceps. H wipes his brow against the sweltering heat and looks arou [Until noted below, this section of the movie is in BLACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get outta the truck in this two- bit town. I got no money and no  prospects. What I need right now is  a stiff drink, a cold shower, and a  hot broad. I'll take 'em in any order  they come...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old three story gothic house in ill-repair beyond a peeli picket fence and a scruffy yard. The sign says -- ROOMS T RENT. The Newcomer goes in the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oh yeah, one other thing I need --  an angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squints through the dirty screen door but sees nothing then knocks and turns away to survey the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking -- if it weren't for  bad luck, I wouldn't have any luck  at all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newcomer turns toward the door. Standing there, holdi the screen open, is the LANDLADY. She's a knockout in a c small-town way: a cotton dress that buttons down the fron and clings with sweat to her generous curves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either my luck had just changed, or  Fate just bought me another round of  trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newcomer's POV of the Landlady as she leads him up th narrow, gloomy stairs from the second floor to the third  story / attic. She has a Monroe-like sway to her walk. We can barely HEAR her DISTANT, ECHOEY DIALOGUE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not very fancy... house needs  repairs... We haven't had a man around  here for so long...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kept yammerin' the whole time,  but her hips were doing all the  talking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Landlady reaches the tiny landing at the top of the s and opens a door to a squalid room with a bed, bureau and tiny window. The Newcomer has to squeeze by her voluptuou body to get inside and look around. It doesn't take long. His gaze returns to the Landlady who is leaning against t door, chest thrust forward. He focusses on her fingers, t with the button at her sweat-shiny cleavage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It couldn't 'a been any clearer what  the set-up was. The next move was up  to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newcomer takes a step in the Landlady's direction --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP of MUMFORD wincing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softer) -- That's all the time we have.  Sorry... (indicates his watch) ...next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Mumford's office: the office of a Psychologist, a  therapist with a doctorate. It's modest, comfortable, nea with a calm, relaxed ambience. [The movie is now in COLOR His patient, HENRY FOLLETT, looks nothing like The Newcom in the soft-core fantasy he's been narrating. Instead, he a mild-looking pharmacist with glasses and a receding  hairline. Only the voice is the same; it's as studly as h fantasy alter-ego. Follett has been lying on a couch, but now has twisted with some irritation to look at Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have eighteen more minutes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear any more today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Follett, do you trust me or don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know... I only been  seeing you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without trust, there's no point to  any of this. You might as well not  come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now hold on, I didn't say I didn't  want to come --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, then go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch crowd. Mumford can be seen out the big front window crossing from the two-story building that houses his offi on the main drag of this small town which, oddly enough, also called Mumford. He comes inside and goes to the coun to pick up some take-out. The Proprietor is a woman aroun forty named LILY, who talks to him as she works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're early... it's not ready. What  happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My patient had to leave early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes over to the register with an order. Mumford is  am[...] her, likes her a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the phrase "nosy" have any  meaning to you, Lily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's like... inquisitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Henry Follett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacts) Man, you see him a lot. And it's  very wrong to reveal it. Next you'll  be saying what his problem is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're terrible. I'm never telling  you anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Patron passes on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Doc... how's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Vincent... how's yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you been in this town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four months, two and a half weeks --  that's how long. (Mumford gives her a  look) And you've already got more patients  than those other two shrinks combined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily, I don't think even you could  know that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily sees something out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that guy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford turns to look out the window. A young man of abou 30, in jeans and a Hawaiian shirt, is skateboarding down street at high speed, weaving in and out amongst the cars He zips past the front of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who that is, don't you? (Mumford does not) You really don't? That's Skip  Skipperton, man. He gets himself hit  by a truck, this whole town shuts  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so that's him? The Panda Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LILY hands over Mumford's bagged order, rings it up. Back track:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what makes you so popular? What's  your secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes his bag to go) You like me. How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not sure. Let me think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is smiling as he goes out. Another Patron, LIONEL DILLARD, a lawyer, brings his check to Lily, watching Mum cross the street. Lily can't stand this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the new psychiatrist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychologist. He's not medical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably thinks he's pretty smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily gives him a look as she takes his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An overweight, teenage girl named NESSA WATKINS is on  Mumford's couch. She fidgets as she talks and can't decid whether to lie down (so she's looking away from him) or s up and face him. She plays with an unlit cigarette and ke taking out a lighter, then stuffing it back in her big, s handbag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so he already had the tattoo that  said, "Naomi Forever"... and now  they're broken up, see, and he has  to have it removed. But while the  scar is still healing, or whatever  you call it when you have a tattoo  removed, he meets Chandra. And it's  serious, immediate love. So in no  time, he's gone from the most gorgeous  model in the world to the most  gorgeous actress in North America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, "in no time"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In maybe three or four issues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weekly or monthly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monthly! God, how shallow do you  think Brad is? Why do I waste my  time telling you this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think you tell me, Nessa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that thing... (Mumford: what?) ...that shrink thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a big part of the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She jams the cigarette in her mouth and flames the lighte but is afraid to actually break his rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really need to let people smoke  in here, you know. It's perverse.  What are they paying you to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford indicates "nothing".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school board doesn't pay you?  What kind of deal is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called pro bono.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pro boner? (he waits her out) Pro bono, huh? For whose good,  supposedly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my bit for the community.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck the community. (he won't go for it) There was this article my friends  and I read. It was "25 Signs He's  Great in Bed". It was very  fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?... The New York Times. The  first one was -- "he handles produce  well." Which we already knew! (an expression she  uses) The point is, you have a lot of the  signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been spying on me in the  supermarket, Nessa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have women found you attractive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you wouldn't answer. I've  been thinking about what you said  last time. How me trying to lose  weight -- and constantly not -- is  like a lot of people with addictions.  How maybe I can't lose the weight,  ever... (quietly) Which we already knew...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not quite what I said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a really weird thing for a shrink  to say... and then you said maybe  people'd be happier if they'd accept  that some things don't change --  that it'd be some kind of a relief  or something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I'm just a dumb bitch,  but how depressing is that moment --  the moment when you give up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last rays of sun are fighting their way through the t as Mumford comes up the trail he clearly knows very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford climbs out on the Big Rock, settles himself on th edge and takes a long drink from a water bottle. WHAT HE SEES: far below at the foot of these hills, light just twinkling on, is the town of Mumford. He stares at i for several long moments. Then he takes a small headlamp  from his pack and fits the straps over his head (it looks like a miner's light). He twists the light on to test it turns his head to watch the beam move about. WE CUT BACK WIDE. After a beat, Mumford settles back and  turns off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is quietly busy with the regulars. Mumford has favorite spot at the far end of the bar. Right now he's  sitting alone, reading the remnants of a newspaper. SKIP SKIPPERTON, the man on the skateboard, comes in. Eve in the bar is surprised to see Skip in here. Several patr greet him as he makes his way deeper inside, looking arou He's uncomfortable. He seems relieved when he spots Mumfo and heads back there. Mumford doesn't notice Skip waiting for his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks up, smiles. Skip offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Doc Mumford. (Mumford nods) Skip Skipperton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Okay. Pretty good. I've been  hoping we'd meet. I've heard a lot  about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford waits, friendly. Skip runs out of gas, gets uneas glances around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we could...? Can I buy  you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. IN A BOOTH near the back. They've been at it a whi but nothing is clear to Mumford, yet. Skip keeps his voic down; he doesn't want anyone else in the bar to hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..."Find the need and fill it" my  dad used to say -- I guess a lot of  dads say that -- but I did and it  just took off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding... Panda. Where'd that  come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panda? I've always liked giant  pandas... I've been to China and  seen them in the wild. That's the  kind of thing I can do if I want...  now. I can do pretty much anything I  want to do these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip stares into his beer for a moment, as though the tho depresses him. He catches himself and snaps back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now we make 23% of the modems in  the market, which is pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip glances around, leans in, confidential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was growing up here, the town  was about dead. The timber business  was played out... Panda changed all  that. Now, just about everybody in  town either works for the company or  depends on it somehow. Which is kinda  the problem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford waits, watches. Skip gets uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like another beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah... scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightens, like a  kid) Far out. Single malt? (gets up) Can I pick it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip heads off to the bar. Mumford looks around. Everybod is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. The bar crowd has thinned. Both Mumford and Skip h had a few. In fact, Mumford is now carefully pouring them each another drink from a bottle of Glensomething on the  table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me... to be... your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip beams. Mumford leans forward in the same confidentia way Skip did before; he indicates that Skip should lean i too. Mumford is almost whispering --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not what's really going  on... (Skip is excited) ...What's really going on is... you  have some problems and you want some  therapy, but you feel it could be  very bad for Panda Modem stock if  word got out that you were having  head problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip confirms that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a personal question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! That's exactly what I  want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you thought about getting a  wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip makes a face and gesture to indicate a large "YES!", but also total frustration and failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Panda started to happen, I was  dating women from New York, San  Francisco, L.A. They came out of the  woodwork. Models, actresses, venture  capitalists... These were not the  kind of girls who were interested in  me before I hit it... And you know  what I discovered? I discovered these  girls did not love me for myself.  The majority of them didn't even  like me. But a lot of them would've  gladly become Mrs. Skipperton for a  while. Can you imagine that --  marrying someone just because they've  got money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford considers that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta pee. (he gets up, a little  wobbly) Can I ask you something? This town  is called Mumford... Been that way  since... 18... 18-0... 18-0... (finally remembers) ...thirteen! Right? (Mumford: if you say  so) Now here's the question -- Your name  is Mumford, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You moved here from back East and  your name is the same as this town.  Is that right? (Mumford shrugs) Far out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip takes a few steps toward the men's room, then comes  back and leans down toward Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't think I want you to  do this for free. Just because we're  gonna play it like we're friends,  doesn't mean I won't pay you like a  doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a lot of money. Do you know  how much money I've got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me, 'cause I'm not going  to tell you what I've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got three big ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm impressed. I couldn't make three  million dollars if I lived three  lifetimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... I have three billion  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip stumbles off to take a leak. Mumford takes a moment digest that. It's difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is listening to Lionel, the arrogant lawyer who a about him in the restaurant. Lionel is lying on the couch talking with enormous energy; he has a serious superiorit complex. Mumford can't stand him and the session seems to lasting an eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so I'm watching Brokaw and they've  got some astronomer, this little  limey know-it-all, and he's telling  how, with this Himball telescope,  they've discovered there are maybe  400 million more galaxies than they  thought there were. And I guess that's  supposed to make me feel small? I'm  supposed to feel insignificant? Is  that the point? Because I can tell  you it didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumfords eyes dart to look at -- THE CLOCK on the bookshelf: 2:23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel, since this is our first  session together, maybe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel is twisting his neck around painfully to look back Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you can sit up and look at me if  you'd like -- (Lionel waves that  off and looks away) -- maybe it would be helpful if you  told me a little about what brought  you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of impatient for a big-time  headshrinker, aren't you? How 'bout  you let me explain it my own way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lionel goes on, Mumford's eyes again dart toward -- TH CLOCK: still 2:23! Hold on it. Finally, it moves. Mumford eyes dart toward his desk -- A deadly-looking letter opener in the shape of Excalibur  stands GLINTING LIGHT in a marble rendition of Arthur's s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and in the dream, it's always the  same, I wake up in my room from when  I was I kid in Ohio, and I realize  this is the day of the big exam at  school...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford's head rocks slowly back for a moment as if he's  going to drift off. He snaps back to life and stares hard the top of Lionel's head, where there is a bald spot star to take hold. The sound of LIONEL'S VOICE begins to echo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...which is no problem for me, because  I remembered it was coming and I've  attended every class, so I'm totally  prepared. Then I see myself running  down the hall at school...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUMFORD'S GLANCE FLASHPANS from Lionel's bald spot to the gleaming letter opener. Mumford closes his eyes. We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy, unmistakably the Young Lionel, runs down the deser hallway toward a bright doorway. [LIONEL'S DREAM has a BL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but it's not really my school --  and this is very interesting -- it's  the school from the next district --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Go on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Lionel comes breathlessly in the classroom door and stares alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And even though I arrive a little  bit early, everybody's already there.  But the surprising part is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT YOUNG LIONEL SEES: Everyone in the class, including Teacher in the front, is naked. The Teacher holds out an  exam toward Young Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm the only one who's prepared!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALTHEA BROCKETT, a woman in her forties, sits on the couc reading a mail order catalogue for home furnishings. Ther are several other catalogues sticking out of her jammed,  woven carry-all. The door to Mumford's inner office opens with some force. Mumford stands looking back across his office at Lionel, is getting up from the couch in some confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you crazy? You can't do this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I can, Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a criminal lawyer -- you think I  like my clients? I can't stand most  of them! But I don't kick them out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that sign -- We retain the right  to refuse service to anyone. I'm not  going to charge you for this session,  but I don't want to see you back  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel looks around, but there is no such sign. He does s Althea watching the show from the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you at least have a back door  I can use?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come out this way. There's no shame  in getting a little therapy... is  there, Althea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Althea stands up, smiling. She thinks Mumford is the bee' knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. It takes guts, Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel steams by them in a black mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe some of us don't need this  crap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's the Hubble Telescope, not  the Himball Telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel bangs out the front door. Mumford motions Althea i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez... what an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Althea heads inside, giggling wildly. She can't get enoug of this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Althea is sobbing. Mumford hands her a new Kleenex from t box next to the couch. She wads it with her current one a tries to stop crying. Mumford settles back in his chair,  patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they want from me? (more sobbing) What have I done that's so wrong? (pulling it together) They act as though they don't have  their own peculiar things... They  do! Believe me. Everybody's got  something... (looks at Mumford) Even you probably have things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me more than most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are they ganging up against me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. But I think they're  worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the kids, you know, not Jeremy.  He had nothing to do with this --  except pay, of course. He's always  willing to pay. He's extremely  generous. (a long beat) I'm so humiliated that my own children  would threaten me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did they threaten you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said if I didn't get help, they  wouldn't deal with me any more. (a beseeching look) What do you think about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Althea stares at him a long moment. She knows he's right. Tears well up in her eyes and roll down her cheeks. She g another Kleenex. In the midst of the torrent she tries to talk, but it's undecipherable:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmfffstttubll abbittmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Althea uses three new tissues to dry up her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said... you must come out to the  house for dinner on Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Jeremy will be home for the  weekend. And you can meet the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford considers, then nods his assent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford hurries up the sidewalk carrying two grocery bags He's late. The modest houses are close together on this p street, which rises out of the main business district, se beyond Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford comes to the house where he lives. He heads down driveway toward the stairs that lead up to his apartment. The front yard is completely fenced. Lily, the owner of t restaurant, is almost visible in there working among the  greenery of a lush garden. Her friendly dog, AINGE, sees  Mumford, leaps easily over the fence and does a circle ar Mumford, who has no free hand to pet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin', Ainge? Evenin', Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc. (doesn't look up) Ainge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog leaps gracefully back into the yard. Mumford hurr up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford comes in and puts the bags down on the kitchen  counter. He goes directly to the table by his main chair picks up the TV remote. He switches it on and changes the channel. The opening segment of UNSOLVED MYSTERIES is jus beginning. It previews the stories on that evening's epis disappearances and unclosed cases -- with Robert Stack  hosting. CLOSE ON MUMFORD'S FACE as he watches. Only when the whol show has been previewed does he seem to relax. He leaves show on as he goes into the kitchen and begins unloading bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is comparing different stepladders. MR. COOK, the sixty-ish proprietor, has been watching from a distance, now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't really know  him) Mr. Cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you come with me please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mystified, Mumford follows Cook through the door into the back. BACK OF THE STORE. Cook motions for Mumford to take the s of honor in the work area, but Mumford prefers to stand.  Cook has a little trouble figuring how to start. Finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I shoulda come to your office.  I was gonna, actually, but then when  you walked in here today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my daughter Sofie... she's gotta  problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not sure. She's been to all  kinds of doctors in the city and  they've said different things. Some  of 'em are callin' it -- (wants to get this  right) -- Epstein-Barr virus, and the rest  are callin' it... Chronic Fatigue  Symptom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Syndrome... Chronic Fatigue Syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it -- syndrome. So you know  all about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... a little. There's a lot of  debate about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got that. Some people think  it's all in their heads. (more intense) It's been so bad she's had to move  back here to Mumford and live with  us. And I'm not sure that's the best  thing, either...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... a lot of things. Several  different factors. Will you see her,  Doctor Mumford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Why don't you bring her up to  my office at 3 tomorrow afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cook nods, but looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure she'll come. She's in a  mood. Do you ever go to somebody's  house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Generally that doesn't work out so  well. It sends the wrong message to  people who need to make a change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cook is quick to agree; he doesn't want to make waves. Bu he's worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is walking up the busy sidewalk carrying his new foot stepladder hooked on his shoulder. Folks greet him.  Suddenly Lionel appears in front of Mumford, who stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to have the right ladder  for the job. You don't know what  you're doing, you can get yourself  in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, as usual. See you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford continues up the street. We STAY WITH Lionel, who watches Mumford with a sour look, then turns to enter a s medical building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. ERNEST DELBANCO, a middle-aged psychiatrist with long vanity hair, and PHYLLIS SHEELER, a psychologist in her  thirties, sit on the doctor's comfortable furniture,  listening. The remains of their take-out lunch is on the  coffee table. They seem a little impatient with their as- unseen visitor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...completely inappropriate and highly  unprofessional. Now I don't want to  presume to tell you how to run your  businesses --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- practices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel is sitting across the room, making an ardent case

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Whatever. Six months ago, you two  were the only games in town. The  value of your... (mocking) ..."practices" could be seriously  undermined by this bozo. A town this  size has only so many headcases to  go around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly would you have us do,  Lionel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Protect your turf! Check this guy  out. I smell a rat, I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delbanco and Sheeler exchange a look; they find Lionel  distasteful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dillard, I'm sure Dr. Delbanco  shares my gratitude for your concern.  But I also know he'd agree that you  misunderstand the nature of our  calling to mental health. We're not  in some... widget business, trying  to crush our competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's a widget?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel comes out of the office, miffed, and goes down the stairs. A moment later, the door opens slightly and Delba peeks out to make sure Lionel is gone. He closes the door us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delbanco stands at the door looking across the room at  Sheeler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What an asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agrees) Ernest, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's got a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So does she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idyllic. The beautifully manicured field is surrounded by lush woods. Standing about forty feet apart, Mumford and  Skip are alone on the field throwing a baseball back and  forth. For quite a while the only sounds are the birds, t wind, and the regular SLAP of ball into glove. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is exactly what I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip, you must have lots of people  you can throw a ball with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised. Most guys have  kids or wives or girlfriends. They're  busy. It's not as easy as you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip, you're the head of the whole  deal here. Are they busier than you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know... that's the thing.  Like I said, just about everybody in  town works for me. And it's just not  the same asking someone to throw a  ball when they work for you. It's  like an order or something... And no  one -- no one -- asks me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford considers. SLAP... SLAP... SLAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, would you say we're out here...  let me think how to put this... Is  your problem really that you're...  lonely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yes, I like it. What's better  than this? Most guys would kill just  to have someone do this with them  whenever they like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a lot of friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("nope") Lily and I talk a bit. You know Lily,  runs the coffee shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I've seen her. Good-looking  woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agrees) She's probably ten years older than  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-looking woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lives downstairs from me. She's got  a great dog named for Danny Ainge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sparks to that) Really? I'm the only person I know  that likes Danny Ainge, outside of  Celtic fans. Maybe Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that Danny Ainge was  drafted by the Blue Jays? Do you  know what kind of athlete you have  to be to play in the NBA and in the  bigs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And Lily named her dog after him?  Far out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of person do you have to  be to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford gestures off in the one direction we have not yet seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE ANGLE: The baseball diamond is sitting in the vas lush grounds behind the PANDA MODEM WORLD HEADQUARTERS, a brand new, distinctively original, high-tech office park. Wherever there is an opportunity for tasteful signage, it in the motif of a Giant Panda -- sweet white face, black  eyes and ears, round body. Skip is suddenly self-conscious, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would've traded any of it to have  made the Mumford High varsity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford takes that in. SLAP... SLAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I guess Henry Follett is a patient  of yours. He's my pharmacist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's got some serious sex fantasies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip is a little surprised to hear this from Mumford, but just throws the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good, too. Lots of detail.  Nothing hard core. Old-fashioned  ones, from back when people cared  about atmosphere and character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problem is, his fantasy life's a lot  better than his real one. Nothing  can live up to it. His wife got sick  of it and left him. Took his kids  with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered what happened to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip is fascinated, but a little uncomfortable. Mumford s oblivious, unusually talkative --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, it's not that simple.  There's something powerful going on  there. We've got a lot of work to  do. (announcer voice) It's hit to the warning track!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Mumford throws the ball way high, lik long fly ball. Skip, delighted as a dog, takes off runnin and just barely catches it on the run. He pegs it back to Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In these fantasies, Henry Follett is  played by a handsome guy with biceps.  Can you imagine that? Where your  self-esteem has to be? (throws him the ball) Man, I'd just like to move the guy  to the point where he gets to appear  in his own fantasies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Nessa sits staring at Mumford defiantly, an unli cigarette in her mouth. Mumford looks at the clock -- 3:0 and stands up, session over. Nessa quickly lights her  cigarette with the lighter concealed in her hand and stan up too. She exhales a huge cloud of smoke and walks quick to the back door of the office, which Mumford has opened her, and goes out. Mumford waves half-heartedly at the cloud of smoke as he  walks to the door to the waiting room and opens it. MUMFORD'S POV: As the door swings open, the first figure see is Mr. Cook; he twists around at the sound of the doo He acknowledges Mumford and then sighs as he steps aside reveal, sitting exhausted in a chair, his daughter -- SOFIE -- a young woman whose actual appearance is somewha disguised at present by her wan, ashen visage. She regard Mumford with some resignation. Her father helps her out o the chair. Sofie keeps her eyes on Mumford. CLOSE ON Mumford, watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Mr. Cook is gone. Sofie is sitting up on the couch facing Mumford. She looks like she might pass out at any  moment, but her voice is stronger than you'd expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel free to lie down. Most people  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better not, I'll fall right to  sleep. I think it's too soon for me  to be sleeping with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A joke. Mumford smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you tell me about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, lord. It's almost too exhausting  to tell you... (tiny smile, to herself) ...about my exhaustion. I didn't  really want to come. I'm not hopeful  right now. But I couldn't take the  look on my dad's face. He's a truly  kind person, which is pretty  extraordinary if you knew the story.  He's the opposite of me, I guess --  all stamina and resolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's taken all her energy to say this and she sinks down bit into the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you start to feel this way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About six months ago, I guess it is  now. God, it seems like years. What  a bore! I'm embarrassed by it. Before  this happened -- when I'd hear people  talk about this kind of thing -- I  thought it was a bunch of bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees something in his face and suddenly laughs -- it' weak but magical sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that now! You think it's a  bunch of hooey, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unconvincing) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it. I saw it in your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is knocked off balance -- she's right. She saw hi clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. Maybe it is. My mother  always says -- "Everything that's  wrong with you is in your head." I  suppose that's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back when this started, was there  anything unusual happening in your  life? A change of job, of living  situation... a loss of some kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... but it started one year to the  day after my divorce became final.  That's not too suspicious, is it?...  But it wasn't like I was feeling bad  about the divorce. Just the opposite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm? Is that a professional opinion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm, as in -- that's interesting.  Sometimes, with enough clues, it's  possible to figure these things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if you don't think it's real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's real and what  isn't. That's never been my strong  suit. But if you're tired all the  time and you've had to give up the  life you were having and come back  home when you didn't want to... that's  worth trying to fix. Maybe I can  help you do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We... we would try several things.  But I need to see you a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I barely made it today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come to you. We'll try a little  walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie suddenly looks defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take it slow. You'll never  feel you can't handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can afford it. I  don't want my dad paying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll work it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie gives him a long look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the best answer for  everything. (Mumford shrugs) You seem so... hopeful. Are you always  this sunny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one ever thought so. You must  bring it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it contagious? 'Cause everyone  agrees my immune system's way down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll catch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something? (Mumford: of course) Didn't you tell my dad you didn't  think it was a good idea to come to  the patient? (he admits it) So what changed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford just smiles. He doesn't want to tell her the trut everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi drops Mumford in front of the Brockett's large and beautiful house, which sits on an isolated lot on the  outskirts of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Althea leads Mumford toward the back of the lavishly appo house. The weird thing, what gets in the way of the decor is the cardboard boxes of all sizes which are stacked  everywhere. Many are unopened, but the rest are spilling  their styrofoam-nugget and bubble-wrap guts to reveal som hint of their contents: a huge variety of catalogue-order housewares, clothing, linens, gadgets, and knickknacks. I it can be ordered from an upscale catalogue (and everythi can), it is here. Althea sounds very nervous, cheery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- sorry everything's in such an  uproar. Lots of big occasions coming  up, and of course Christmas is only  eight months away -- (giggles uncontrollably) -- I don't know what's keeping Jeremy.  You know he stays in the city three  nights a week -- I guess I explained  that... (Mumford nods) ...I know Katie's here, but I'm not  so sure about Martin... I'm making  dinner myself tonight, so I'll have  to leave you, I'm afraid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come out onto the wide porch, which commands a  spectacular view of the surrounding countryside. There's elaborate bar cart out here, which Althea points Mumford  toward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm awful I know, but will you please  help yourself. I just got a new copper  sauciere from Williams-Sonoma and  I'm afraid it'll be the death of us  all if I don't get back in there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She disappears inside with a bang of the screen door. Mum gets a drink for himself, taking in the view. He sees  something out there. MUMFORD'S POV: Way in the distance, coming out of the woo and down toward the house is a teenage boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the doctor, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford turns to see that Althea's thirteen year old daug KATIE has silently appeared. Her jeans and little tee-shi are meant to be sexy; it seems sad on her. Mumford nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Katie. People call me  Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning urgently) C'mere. Quick... c'mon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford follows as she disappears around the corner of th porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford follows Katie into a gloomy hall from a side entr Here too, the walls are lined with boxes. She tiptoes to of two facing doors and waits for him. When he has joined her, she motions him back a foot for  safety, then carefully opens the door to a large walk-in  closet. Katie's caution becomes understandable: the space packed so fully and chaotically with catalogue item carto that it might come tumbling out the door with one careles move. Katie closes the door, then pirouettes to the oppos door, which she swings open freely -- REVEALING: what was once a study is now completely filled with hundreds of  cartons, in an infinite variety of shapes and sizes. Mumford is taken aback. Katie points at packages and spea in a hypnotic WHISPER --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuddledown... Linen & Lace... Scully  & Scully... Smith & Hawken... Plow &  Hearth... Museum of Modern Art...  Smithsonian Museum... J. Crew...  Wolferman's... Hold Everything...  Nieman Marcus... Coldwater Creek...  Garnett Hill... Norm Thompson...  Victoria's Secret... Sharper Image...  Hammacher Schlemmer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Mumford and Katie come back around the corner, MA Althea's sixteen year old son, crosses the yard and comes onto the porch. He's wearing an old black leather jacket  with a lot of zippers, dirty jeans and black Converse All Stars that are coming apart. In his hand, casually but  properly held, is a .22 caliber rifle. He looks Mumford o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) I showed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mumford) Do you get it now? This is no joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford takes them both in and nods. He understands. Sudd their manner changes, for the worse. What they can see th Mumford cannot is JEREMY BROCKETT, Althea's husband, who come to the back screen door, with the bustle of a late  arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, kids. Oh, hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing Mumford, Jeremy steps out onto the porch to shake hand. Jeremy is quite handsome and a fantastic dresser; h Armani outfit cost $4200 all in. His tone: hearty and str

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Dr. Mumford of Mumford.  Jeremy Brockett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late... traffic was a  motherfucker. Have another drink,  I'll be back in five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy goes inside. Martin and Katie exchange a look with each other, then to Mumford. Martin goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Dinner is over. Jeremy comes out onto the veranda  carrying two Cuban cigars. His casual outfit is as stylis and pricey as his work outfit. He joins Mumford and Althe who immediately gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes inside. The men each have a snifter of cognac. J makes a ceremony of cutting the cigars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'll like this. Know much  about Cuban cigars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy puts the cigars down, pulls a joint out of his cas pullover and fires it up. After exhaling a huge cloud of  smoke, he offers the joint to Mumford, who declines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes the whole thing that much  better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy takes another hit on the joint and puts it down. H gives a cigar and his gold lighter to Mumford, who begins light up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hold the flame a little bit  below the end... that's it... now  just turn it slowly as you draw...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford does as he's told. Jeremy lights his own cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a man who likes to treat  himself right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had my moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. And I'm not ashamed of it.  Nobody ever said on their death bed --  "I treated myself too well."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was -- Nobody ever said,  "I should have spent more time at  the office."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fill in the blank. I don't mind the  office. The point is, you only go  'round once. Like the Zens say -- Be  here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Althea hasn't told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no) We've been talking about her, mostly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in '85 four of us left our  firms and formed an investment banking  venture. We've got twenty-three people  working there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marijuana is kicking in now -- Jeremy gets a self- satisfied, condescending look on his face that no straigh mind would dare. His response includes their lavish immed surroundings--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've done... very well. You know  anything about addiction, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm addicted to winning. I say  when you're in the red zone, you  gotta score. (watches Mumford smoke) So what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tastes good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I mean about Althea. About  her... (makes a face) ...behavior. Do you think you can  fix her up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think's wrong with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone weird is what's wrong  with her. Out of control. Probably  from living out here in Mayberry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy blows cigar smoke into his snifter, then takes a  mouthful of cognac, savoring the sensations. Mumford watc fascinated by this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the doctor, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seems very unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy gives him a look, as if to say "duh."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we all knew that, professor.  The question... the real -- (drawn out, stoned) -- quest-tio-nee... is... why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks at him a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy Brockett's Mercedes 500 SL whips around a curve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin is driving Mumford back to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know how to drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a license? (yes) But no car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got my license two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been drivin' since I was twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would explain it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you help Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intense) Got to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive in silence for a bit. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nessa Watkins... She comes to you,  doesn't she? You're treating her,  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford gives him a surprised look, then acknowledges it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she a friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... sort of. Man, she could be  cool, but all she does is get wrecked  and do all the guys. She's blowin'  them in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford knew that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A person's got to hate themselves to  act like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford regards Martin with respect, then turns to look o front. After a few moments --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever met a bigger shithead  than my stepfather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily is walking Ainge as the Mercedes pulls up and Mumfor gets out. Ainge runs happily around the car and puts his  paws up on the driver's door to greet Martin; we HEAR the clicking SCRATCH of his nails on the surface. Martin rubs the dog's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ainge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. Jeremy won't mind. Good  dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ainge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog obediently leaves Martin and runs back to Lily.  Mumford waves as Martin pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ainge) Do we run into the street? No, I  didn't think so. (looks after Martin) Nice car. How's that place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pretty piece of land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk up the block with the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Brocketts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horror show. What'd you do tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was insane here, man. 'Hadda call  in the National Guard. (he nods) Then I did my laundry... watched  20/20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shocking. Did you know the government  is wasteful? (Mumford reacts) You heard it here first. Oh, and  being a supermodel... it's no walk  in the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No gentleman caller, Doc. (they turn back) Not that I care. I've had it with  men. They're so fascinated by their  own crap. Took me four years to get  the last one out. Almost turned me  into a dyke... These days my idea of  a hot date is a long shower by myself  before bed. Now that feels good. And  you don't have to do all that...  listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops... sorry. I guess that's the  story of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON COMPUTER SCREEN. A health information "library"  website has been called up on Mumford's office computer.  Right now it's beginning to spew information about "CHRON FATIGUE SYNDROME" -- Definitions, Signs and Symptoms,  Diagnostic Measures, etc. Mumford is hunched over the computer, reading avidly. His printer is churning out hard copies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford comes out the front door and holds it open for So He offers his arm and she takes it tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not making any promises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll turn back anytime you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing something) Oh boy... this should be interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks out toward the street. A woman in her fifti is turning into the front walk. She stares at them, unsmi as the two parties converge. She is MRS. COOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mother. I want you to meet  Dr. Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford... like the town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering his hand) Yes. It's nice to meet you, Mrs.  Cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finally takes his hand, but it's not friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that's a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mumford does, yes. I've put myself  completely in his hands. For today,  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of doctor are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ph.D., psychologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... not a real doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, the fake kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cook is not amused. Sofie pulls on Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd better go or I'm liable to bail  on the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cook steps aside as they move up the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford and Sofie, foreground, walk slowly up the block. the background, Mrs. Cook watches for awhile before going inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom's such a cutie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People usually have to get to know  me before they hate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not in a bad mood. She's like  that all the time. (a beat) It doesn't bother me anymore. It's  my dad and my brother I worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... but you're the one whose  ass is dragging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Is that the technical description of  what I've got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she against you getting help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't discuss it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's bothering her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we've all disappointed her. Me,  especially, but Dad, of course. She  thinks my brother's all right, but  she didn't expect much. It's what  happens when you "marry beneath  yourself"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie suddenly seems to be fading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negative thinking makes everything  more difficult. If you're going to  have enough strength to do this, we  have to talk only about positive  things. All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, unsure if he's serious. It seems so cor But she agrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then... Are you positive your  mother's a bitch? (she laughs, surprised) Just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a funny idea of funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seems worried) I've offended you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? What would it take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs again; surprised again. He's got her off balan makes a "rim shot" sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the treatment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry... I'm done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I'll tell you, none of the  others have tried this approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've come to the corner. He gestures to ask -- "shall cross?" She considers for quite a while, gauging her stre then, still on his arm, steps off the curb --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absurdly unconvincing) Hey, 'Just do it!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY CROSS OUT OF FRAME as we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to tell me all your  symptoms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER DAY. They're dressed differently. Sofie seems mor vigorous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm embarrassed. The list is so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be specific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I'm tired all the time,  obviously. I always feel like taking  a nap. But when I try to sleep, I  have trouble. (Mumford nods) My muscles ache. And my joints. I  feel like an old person, or like I  did back when I used to work out too  hard... What else?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON COMPUTER SCREEN. Under the list of Signs and  Symptoms: "Sore throat."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sore throat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE SCREEN: "Low grade fever... Painful lymph glands.. Irritability..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low grade fever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Painful lymph glands? (yes) Forget fulness... irritability...  depression?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, and definitely yes. Also...  I get confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, most people have that. It's  confusing here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER DAY. Mumford is leading Sofie through the lightes set of calisthenics ever devised. Now they're doing waist bends and arm waving. Even so, it's taking everything Sof got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I mentioned the  headaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get headaches before this? (Sofie: yes) But you get more now? Or more severe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not really. They're about the  same. My marriage was one long  headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the headaches may not even be a  part of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She considers that, reluctantly agrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give myself a headache  instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that like a party trick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I have to do is have two  conflicting thoughts at the same  time... Like I'll think -- 'Taking  these walks is going to help Sofie  get better.' But then I'll also think --  'Mumford, you just enjoy taking these  walks and you're kidding yourself  about the benefits.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie's not sure how to take that. She looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There... I've given myself a real  whopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You actually address yourself by  name in your thoughts? (Mumford laughs) So you really think having two  opposing ideas in your head does  some kind of damage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, yeah... pulling in two  different directions at once. It  makes tiny little tears in our fabric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, my life has been some  kind of huge rip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The handsome Newcomer of Follett's fantasy comes down the steps from the attic wearing a sleeveless undershirt, tow thrown over his shoulder. He goes into the bathroom off t second floor hall and begins to wash up. [Again, Follett' fantasy world is in BLACK & WHITE.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town was a rube's heaven, but I  found work my first day out down at  Old Man Sutter's gas station and  diner. I knew his stacked young wife  was going to be a problem, but, hey,  life is full of problems. Back at  the boarding house, I was washing up  when I heard a load of yellin' and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE BATHROOM MIRROR, the Newcomer's POV: a nubile teen 17 going on 35, in a tight cheerleader's outfit, comes up the stairs and stops at the top to turn and yell back dow at her mother. Her dialogue distant and echoey:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...get off my case! You don't like  any of my friends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I got my first look at the  landlady's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LANDLADY'S DAUGHTER looks up and sees the Newcomer  watching her through the half-open bathroom door. She giv him a petulant, white-hot look, then turns on her heel an goes into her room at that end of the hall. She bangs her door behind her, but it bounces open again about a foot. Newcomer, still watching in the bathroom mirror, now has view of the bureau mirror in the Landlady's Daughter's ro In there, seemingly oblivious, the girl quickly strips of the top of her outfit, revealing a '50's-era white bra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky for me, she was plenty upset  but not too careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, in mirror reflection of mirror, the Landlady's  Daughter meets the Newcomer's smoldering stare and her li begins to curl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe it wasn't an accident at  all --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Follett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- 'cause in that instant I saw the  beginning of a vixen's smile and I  knew --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mysteriously, the door to the girl's bedroom slams shut,  cutting off the Newcomer's view. He looks with surprise i his mirror -- it suddenly shatters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett sits up abruptly on the couch and twists toward  Mumford, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? I'm paying for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for this. Not me, you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (challenging) You find it distasteful, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter how I feel about  it. It's how you feel about it that  matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enjoy it. Does that make me some  kind of pervert? Just because a man  has a rich imaginative life --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't come to me because you  have a rich imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came because it's taking over.  You're in its grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford's tone suddenly picks up a touch of steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your wife, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett flinches, settles back down onto the couch, sulki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your wife, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softer) I didn't hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett mutters something to himself, then is silent unti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got divorced. (petulant) I had to get rid of her. She couldn't  satisfy me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts, Follett jumps) What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett seems to shrink in size. They've been here before and he doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I was... never satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (normal again) Now we're back on track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, Follett says something under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long beat) You are so mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford strides up the trail on his late day excursion. H comes around a bend and is surprised to find Skip waiting for him, looking serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Skip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc. I know we're not supposed to  get together till Wednesday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. What's on your  mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford indicates that Skip should walk with him up the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many sessions have we had now,  Doc? (Mumford tries to  remember) Six. And it's been good... like we  were two buddies hanging out. Just  shootin' the shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is really hard. Everything I  want to say is hard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford and Skip come out of the trees, climb onto the bi rock, and settle down. The sun is falling over the town o Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We're like friends, almost... who  trust each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks Mumford's reaction. Mumford nods, offers Skip w who turns it down. Mumford takes a swig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to tell you something, Doc,  but before I do, I need to ask you a  question... Because, for me to tell  you this thing -- well, I haven't  told anybody about this. It's the  biggest secret I've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it's best to keep a few  things just for ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a shrink, Doc. Aren't I  supposed to be able to tell you  everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip, even more unsure now, looks away, at the town below

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That really relates to the thing I  want to ask you... I've noticed that  sometimes, not a lot, but sometimes,  when we're hanging out, throwin' the  ball... or that time we went  bowling... sometimes you'll like -- (gets it out fast --) -- tell me things about your other  patients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford lets that hang a few moments, then acknowledges i silently. Now Skip is even more nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, maybe that's all right! I don't  know all that much about psychology  or therapy or... ethics, so maybe  there's something I missed... or  something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're concerned that maybe I can't  be trusted with a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust you. Definitely. No question.  But, yeah, I'm a little concerned. I  mean, you're not supposed to tell  anyone about your patients'  problems... are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks at Skip for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct, Skip. I'm going to  have to take a long look at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conversation seems to end there. Skip's not sure wher to go next. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... what I was gonna tell  you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Skip. Knowing what you do about  me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc, I trust you! You've listened to  me better than anybody... maybe ever. (leans in, intense) And this secret I've got, I can't  stand it anymore. I don't know if  I'm some kind of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip looks around at the darkening woods, though clearly  there's no one around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I don't know if I'm a pervert or  what. It's taken me this long to get  where I can come out and say it... I  can't back away now. I can't spend  another day not knowing if I'm nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip closes his eyes for a second and gathers himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'm just gonna tell you,  as simple and direct as I can. (one last spasm of  doubt) And you understand that this is a  big secret? Just between us? (Mumford does) Okay. You know I've got this gift  for certain kinds of... machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are Panda, monarch of modems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. And you also know that  even though I make 23% of the modems  in the world... I cannot make one  simple connection with any woman who  could truly love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... let's say that, for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true, believe me. So... do you  know what I've been doing, all alone,  in my workshop, for almost two  years?... Mr. Find-the-Need-and-Fill- It. How I spend my every solitary  hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford shakes his head, "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess. (Mumford demurs) Go ahead, guess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (if he must) Jerking off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!... Although that's a good guess.  No, what I've been working on, what  the world really needs and no one  has been able to create -- (leans in, whispering) -- a virtually life-like, humanoid,  gender-specific, anatomically  functional... sexual surrogate slash  companion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford tries to put that all together. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slash what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sexual surrogate... slash...  companion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A doll?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Doc, not a doll. I am Panda. I'm  talking about much, much more than a  doll. The world has never seen what  I'm talking about... except maybe in  the movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford considers that a long time, watching as the sun  finally sinks below the horizon. He looks back at Skip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I'm insane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("no") And that's your secret? (Skip: "yes") You meant -- like a trade secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Doc, a private secret! It's  perverted, it's pitiful. What am I --  Dr. Frankenstein? Aren't you repulsed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like kind of a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonplussed) Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting dark fast now. Mumford reaches into his bag takes out the headlamp we saw earlier. He fits the straps carefully over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip, that's not much of a secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt) It's not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's okay. It's just not something  to be ashamed of. Maybe you don't  want people knowing -- and believe  me, it's safe with me -- but on the  scale of dirty little secrets, I'd  give it, say... a two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford twists the headlamp and the light shines out in t dusk. Mumford turns the beam directly at Skip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know a secret? I'll tell  you a secret. Since it's just between  us and all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip, hanging on every word now, agrees emphatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The secret, Skip, is this -- I am  not now, nor have I ever been... a  psychologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first, Skip thinks he's misunderstood Mumford. But in huge silence that ensues, he replays it and knows he's he right. Mumford looks around, adjusts his headlamp, and ge up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd better get going. Just follow  my light. And, Skip, watch your step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This porch is directly above Lily's porch. Mumford and Sk sit nursing beers. There's a cooler on the floor. Mumford legs are propped up on the porch railing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
