dialogues.text: It's time you did some talkin', Dr.  Mum -- Wait a minute. That is your  name, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford takes a drink of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. You can call me Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It matters to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford gestures: "sorry, no can do."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told you a lot of private stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about everything? How did this  happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks at Skip, considering. He takes a long pull  from his beer, then looks at the frosty bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that every species of  mammal has found some way to drug,  inebriate, or anestnetize itself?  Even if it's just banging its head  against a rock. Seems to be some  natural urge... to get away for a  while. (one more look at  Skip) I've had it for as long as I can  remember. The first place I wanted  out of was home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS MUMFORD TALKS we SEE IMAGES FROM HIS PAST, all FROM  MUMFORD'S POV. We do not see him in the scenes. Instead,  everyone else in the scene RELATES TO THE CAMERA AS MUMFO even if they're just ignoring him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGIC
dialogues.text: MOVING FAST (MUMFORD'S CHILDHOOD POV) toward the back doo of a rundown, little house in a poor mining community. We reach the back door and bang inside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cramped interior is grimy and depressing. MUMFORD'S M worse for wear, has just put a glass of liquor on the sin and returned her attention to the smoking stovetop. She  glances briefly at Mumford and greets him pleasantly, cle drunk. Suddenly, her attention shifts and we -- PAN TO TH FRONT DOOR which is opened roughly by MUMFORD'S FATHER, a coal miner whose face still shows the grime of his work. it's his scary scowl that impresses. His eyes take in his wife (and her drink) but he says nothing. He barely gives Mumford a glance as he drops his lunch pail on the table disappears into another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I had the best parents in  Bald Knob, West Virginia... till I  was seven years old and got a look  at some others. They weren't bad  folks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT THE DINNER TABLE. Across the table, MUMFORD'S OLDER SI eats with her head down. On the right, Mumford's Mother i picking at her food. Mumford's POV shifts to his Father, is yelling something at his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but they were real unhappy about  being who they were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, his Father looks suddenly at Mumford; his hand shoot out to slap Mumford's face, and the IMAGE GOES BLACK, the immediately FADES UP AGAIN on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON A TEST PAPER being laid on an old-fashioned stud desk. Scrawled in red pencil at the top: "A -- Outstandin TILT UP to the old classroom, full of kids getting their  tests back. ACROSS THE AISLE, looking at camera with disg is a sixteen year old boy, MUMFORD'S CLASSMATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It made no sense that school came  easy for me... I didn't do much work,  and there was a proud tradition in  my family of being really dumb. My  friends didn't like it much. It made  them distrust me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM INSIDE A HELMET: the brutal chaos of crashing bodies a Friday night high school football game. Mumford is viol hit. Our view is smashed so deep into the muddy turf that again the IMAGE GOES BLACK, then quickly FADES UP AGAIN o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON A CAN OF "IRON CITY" BEER in MUMFORD'S POV as he puts it on the roof of a green Nash Rambler and ducks int the back seat. In the shadows is a teen-age girl, MUMFORD DATE. As Mumford moves toward her, she flames a Bic light and gleefully lights a fat joint; her blouse is unbuttone and gaping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other hand, it made some of  my classmates like me better... I  don't know what it was in me, maybe  some genes from my mom, maybe some  discomfort with myself, but early on  I was drawn to any substance that  made me numb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graduation Ceremonies. MUMFORD'S POV moving across a plat toward the diploma being proffered by the PRINCIPAL. PAN Mumford's Parents, dressed up and proud, in the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I got a scholarship to go out  of state to college, I was the first  one in my extended family who'd gone  beyond high school. At graduation,  my folks looked like a normal, happy  couple, which I guess they were about  10% of the time... out in public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON A DORM ROOM DOOR as it is pushed open. MUMFORD'S NEW ROOMMATE, a crazed, middle-class doper, has his stuff spread around and is settled in the midst of the chaos. H looks up at the arriving Mumford with a maniacal, stoned  smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My roommate was from a planet I had  never heard of called Scarsdale,  where everything was the opposite of  West Virginia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON A BONG filling with white smoke. We FOLLOW IT UP THE TUBE to a PRETTY COED, who inhales deeply, then blows seductive cloud directly at Mumford. The room is full of  partying students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the other kids, in fact, seemed  to know things I didn't. They were  friendly enough, but in four years,  I never got over feeling that I had  sneaked in... and was about to be  exposed as the hillbilly and imposter  I actually was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funky decor, red scarf over the lamp creating a sexy glow MUMFORD'S POV moves toward an undulating shape hidden by sheet on the bed. He reaches out and lifts the edge to RE the Pretty Coed, now naked, giggling, her extended hand  offering a tab of acid right up to camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing that always made those  feelings go away was... fun. Fun was  drugs, fun was sex, fun was  aggressively doing nothing. The only  problem I had with degenerate, self- destructive behavior was... I couldn't  get enough of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PROFESSOR approaches camera and lays a fresh examinatio on the desk in front of Mumford. The problem is -- Mumfor is so doped up the classroom is swimming and the examinat paper keeps changing shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that fun eventually had an impact  on the work I was doing. I figured,  what the hell, it was only college,  after all. I'd straighten up when I  went out in the real world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON SEVERAL AMPHETAMINE CAPSULES being dumped into  Mumford's palm over a water fountain. They disappear towa camera as we dip down toward the stream of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to jump into my career  right out of college. And since I  had no career, that turned out to be  not much of a problem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUMFORD'S POV lifts from the fountain and turns to the  endless, deserted corridor of the huge building. We begin TRACKING DOWN the hall, checking out the various doorways Cleaning Crew appears far up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a series of challenging jobs  over the next few years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN from the back of a garbage truck to a mess of garb containers, and MOVE TOWARD THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON TWO LINES of cocaine. We DIP TOWARD THEM, then U AGAIN and they're gone. PAN to REVEAL we're in a closet o the brightly-lit office of an all-night gas station. A PA is waiting impatiently out by the pumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO PRESENT. Skip watches Mumford intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...pizza delivery, pipe fitting,  pest control... lots of jobs that  started with the letter "p". For  some reason, I kept losing these  jobs. (takes a swig of beer) The only mind-altering substance I  never had a problem with was alcohol.  I never got drunk. I didn't like the  feeling. But really, when you're as  fucked up as I was... big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford stands up and stretches, then sits on the railing facing Skip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually, doing all these different  jobs, I noticed something. For some  reason, probably because I was too  stoned to talk, everywhere I went --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see various CO-WORKERS from Mumford's jobs. The  environments are radically different, but the activity is always the same -- the Co-Worker in question is pouring h heart out to camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- people would talk to me, tell me  everything... their stories, their  problems, their innermost thoughts.  Sometimes they'd pretend they needed  advice, but mostly people just wanted  someone to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUMFORD'S MOVING POV as he crawls into the darkness, an  insecticide sprayer ahead of him. He pushes at a cinderbl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, one day I was spraying for  termites when I had a vision --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cinderblock tips over and a swarm of scary-looking sp comes rushing out toward camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- it was time to put my college  degree to work and get a job with a  desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM BEHIND A DESK in the middle of a huge sea of desks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took the civil service exam and  found myself working at the Internal  Revenue Service, District 14, Central  Administrative Office. I started off  as a general records clerk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS: computer records scrolling rapidly, pape files being pulled, documents being routed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess the standards weren't too  high there, because my superiors got  excited and pushed me to take the  advancement tests...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An intense basketball game. The ball zips from behind cam (Mumford) to an older guy, MUMFORD'S SUPERVISOR, under th basket; he lays it in easily, then comes over to high-fiv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One guy in particular thought I should  be a Revenue Officer. There was more  money to be made as your  classification went up. Which had a  lot of appeal to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COCAINE MILL is loaded with white chunks and screwed sh in MUMFORD'S POV; the steady grinding begins. Spread acro the messy kitchen table is the regular user's paraphernal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...since, even though I was certain  I could stop anytime I wanted, I had  developed a real affection for  cocaine. It was my favorite hobby I  had ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUMFORD'S POV SHIFTS around the office. First, he's looki at an irate TAXPAYER yelling across a desk at a REVENUE  OFFICER, who remains unruffled --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I sure didn't want to be a Revenue  Officer, where you were face to face  abusing -- and getting abused -- all  day long...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His POV PANS with a couple of intense COLLECTION AGENTS w pass behind the first scene on their way out of the offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And being a Collection Agent was  definitely not in my genetic make- up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His POV STOPS, letting the Collection Agents go, on anoth fellow, with the disreputable, cocksure demeanor of a pri dick, who is lolling near the water cooler, watching the  altercation with amusement. He is GREGORY, an IRS  INVESTIGATOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there was one job that looked  like it might be fun -- Investigator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you telling me your last job  before becoming a psychologist was --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO PRESENT. Skip is leaning intensely toward Mumford

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- an investigator for the Internal  Revenue Service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody has a story, Skip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you have several.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it felt like was... a series of  separate, unconnected lives --  hillbilly kid, wrecked college boy,  garbage man, civil service guy... (Yul Brynner accent) ...et cetera... et cetera. Every  time I'd leave a life, it felt good.  Whatever problems I was having were  suddenly gone. I had no friends and  I didn't talk to my family. The only  constant, stabilizing force in my  life was... drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An IRS investigator with a drug  problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't the best situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you carry a gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't need one. We didn't even need  a warrant for most of the shit we  did. Man, the IRS... we could go in  your bank account, your credit  cards... hell, we used to go into  doctors' files and get all the juicy  details. Nobody wants to argue with  the IRS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING POV as Mumford follows GREGORY down the gloomy all to a corner where they can spy at the scene beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got teamed with one of the top  guys, a fanatic named Gregory. He  always got his man, whether they  deserved it or not. He was a "closer"  and everybody admired that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT THEY SEE: The DRY CLEANING BOSS, a Middle-Eastern fe is standing at the back door of his place paying his Asia employees in cash as they leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd make the case and the Collection  guys would come in and clean up. Our  specialty was... sleazy skulking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory turns to look at camera (Mumford) with a devilish grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were a good team. I was a dope  addict and Gregory was insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUMFORD'S POV as he supports a drunken Gregory as they st down the sidewalk to a row house. Holding Gregory up on t other side, is CANDY, Gregory's pretty wife. They wrangle Gregory up the front steps. Gregory stumbles inside and  Mumford retreats down the steps, his eyes still on the fr door. Candy appears there and stares down at Mumford, who stops where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, him being insane didn't  make it all right that I fell in  love with his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford settles back in his chair as Skip shakes his head astounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (announcer-like) "Get to know your therapist."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were messed up, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dry) But look at me now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you've done good. Look at  yourself... you've cleaned up, you've  got a career --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip stops, remembers the truth, realizes. Mumford smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you pulled yourself out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things got a lot worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Candy...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUMFORD'S POV from his bed. Candy finishes dressing acros the room. She looks at camera, her face full of the pain leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING POV as Mumford follows Gregory up the ladder and o the roof of this old building in a rundown industrial  neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way the District Managers got  ahead and won their bonuses was by  generating maximum payments. That  meant the revenue officers had to  use all their "collection tools" --  seizures, liens, levies -- even if a  more reasonable compromise could  have been worked out. The best way  to reduce resistance from the  taxpayers was to build a convincing  case -- whether there'd actually  been a violation or not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford follows Gregory, crawling, to the edge of the roo and looks down on a building one block over. It is a smal furniture factory. Employees are eating their lunches on loading dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where we came in. Our DM was  a particular sonuvabitch, and he  knew just how to get Gregory crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUMFORD'S POV takes in his ATTRACTIVE DATE next to him, t PANS TO Candy and Gregory across the table. Everybody's  laughing. Candy flashes Mumford a momentary special look. MUMFORD'S POV guiltily PANS TO Gregory. Did he see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So several things were working on  Gregory when we started building a  case against a furniture maker named  Edmond Worrell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BINOCULAR VIEW of EDMOND WORRELL and MRS. WORRELL as they get in a Cadillac at the end of a workday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lit by powerful flashlights, Gregory and Mumford attack t files of the company, both in cabinets and on computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory was acting more and more  irrational. We started doing things  that were over the line even for the  IRS. When I look back on it now, I'm  sure Gregory must have known about  Candy and me. On our team, I had  become...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE-UP A LINE OF COCAINE on the top of a toilet tank as it is sucked out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the responsible one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUMFORD'S POV IS A BLURRY SHAPE until Candy moves up and  away, her face sweaty and aroused, torso naked. She's on of Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford's POV slides into the passenger seat. Gregory is  already sitting in the driver's seat. He stares at Mumfor long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is following Gregory and REVENUE OFFICER MCLURE d the hall. They reach a door with the painted sign: "SAMUE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes when a case didn't work  out right, Gregory and this Revenue  Officer named McLure would put the  squeeze on the subject's accountant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start to enter, SOFT CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GORBECK listens, intimidated by McLure, who sits on the  accountant's desk, and Gregory, who is moving around the  office -- snooping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't many accountants who  don't have something to worry about  with the Service...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edmond Worrell, his wife, his adult SON and DAUGHTER,  WORRELL'S LAWYER, and, finally, the accountant Gorbeck ar ushered toward a conference room by McLure, Gregory and s other IRS types. Gorbeck sneaks a nervous look at Mumford Gregory, who now appears slightly mad, motions for Mumfor to join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parties met repeatedly over a  period of months. The IRS offered to  settle for a sizable but, they said,  fair amount. Worrell said he'd done  nothing wrong and threatened to fight  it all the way to Washington. He  seemed pretty strong. I was secretly  pulling for him. McLure and the  District Manager stepped up the  pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING POV OUT THE WINDSHIELD of Gregory's government car it comes speeding into the parking lot. There are two fla Squad Cars and an Ambulance at the entrance. As Gregory's car hits a speedbump, the IMAGE BEGINS TO SLOW DOWN --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What none of us down at the Service  knew was that Edmond Worrell had a  story too... Worrell's was that he'd  been fighting chronic depression for  thirty years. Under the heat of the  investigation, he fell off his  medication. One Tuesday morning, he  went down to the factory early, wrote  his family a letter, then used the  9mm automatic they kept there to  kill himself... The DM dropped the  case that day and started proceedings  to get rid of Gregory...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The IMAGE HAS SLOWED TO A STILL. It now DISSOLVES TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford's POV as he comes up the steps. The front door op before he gets there. Candy, her face bruised, her eyes r comes into view, she has a suitcase in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory went home drunk, beat up  Candy and went out to drink some  more. Candy told me she didn't want  to see me again. She hated us both  and she was leaving us both... It  made perfect sense to me. I felt the  same way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is frantically, futilely looking for an imagined  drug stash. He's ransacked the place and is now throwing clothes out of a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks desperately through the pill bottles and  detritus in his squalid medicine cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...In fact, I was jealous of Candy.  I wanted to leave too, just like  her... get as far away from --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giving up, Mumford slams the medicine cabinet shut and FO THE FIRST TIME SINCE HIS STORY BEGAN, WE SEE MUMFORD in h previous incarnation. And this is probably as bad as he e looked. He stares at his image in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- me... as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip is staring at Mumford. Empty beer bottles are lined on the porch railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so you did...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the drugs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harder than I thought. Took me three  tries. But I was highly motivated --  figured there was no point in leaving  me and taking that along. After two  bomb-outs, I found a place in the  desert...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A venetian blind is raised, revealing sunrise over a dese landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joint wasn't fancy -- it was run  by an order of monks -- but it worked.  When I got out of there, I was just  about broke...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford gets up from his chair and moves toward his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...which seemed perfect for starting  something new. Be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford goes inside. Skip sits listening to the night. Fr downstairs, in Lily's apartment, he HEARS A SHOWER GO ON. Mumford comes back out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's taking a shower down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could live in the shower.  I'd take five a day if I had the  time. I went to this spa in Germany,  a sanitarium practically, up on this  mountain. And the great thing --  they just kept you wet all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you go with? (Skip: "alone") That's not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you do it? (Mumford is confused) The new you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how easy it is. A kid can  manage it if he wants a fake I.D.  You can do practically the whole  deal at your local Kinko's. The only  variable is how much pride you take  in the product.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it starts with a birth  certificate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All new people start with that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A COMPUTER SCREEN an elaborate graphics program is cre the filigreed border of a birth certificate that already  bears the official-looking designs of "Green County, Stat of West Virginia".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With desktop publishing, you don't  have to deal with printers, supply  houses, or pesky government agencies.  Eventually you do have to get your  hands on a typewriter. Ever seen one  of those, Skip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the border is completed, we PUSH IN and DISSOLVE THROU

dialogues.speaker: TO
dialogues.text: SURFACE OF A DESK, with an electric Smith-Corona typewrit (late '50's vintage). EXTREME CLOSE-UP of the keys hammer out individual letters and numbers: date, hospital, atten physician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along) Is that like a mimeograph?... What  about the name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks at Skip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mumford"... I mean, why pick the  name of the town you were going to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. You got it backwards. I already  had the name when I started looking  for somewhere to settle. When I saw  this town on a map, I thought maybe  it was a sign. See...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The typewriter is just pounding out: MICHAEL OLIVER MUM-F R-D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mickey Mumford was in Miss Rice's  kindergarten class with me. He was  killed with his parents in a wreck  on their way back from a Steelers  game. He was only six years old,  which is a real plus, so there's a  birth certificate if anyone checks --  but not much else. They died in  Pennsylvania, so there's no death  certificate in West Virginia... that's  also good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A KITCHEN TABLE, the new birth certificate, now filled out for Michael Mumford, is carefully lifted from a shall bowl of light tea (the tea bags are nearby). The paper ha taken on an aged, sepia look. CUT TO: A STACK OF BOOKS. The ones on top are lifted away. The bo book is opened to reveal the birth certificate. It has be folded in an official way. Now Mumford unfolds it, then  refolds it differently -- with its smudges and creases, i starting to look old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a birth certificate is enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything flows from that, and what  doesn't... can be easily purchased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS of Mumford's DOCUMENTATION PILING UP. A p office box is emptied, official-looking correspondence is opened, the bounty is laid out for perusal: Social Securi card, driver's license, college and graduate school diplo license and accreditation to operate as a therapist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, my IRS training made it  easier. Once you've done that, there's  not much data you can't access and  use any way you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a free society, you are who you  say you are. (smiling) People should remember that before  they go around knocking this country. (he gets up) Skip, all this beer's got me sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip looks upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you studied psychology, right?  You did the training and just never  got the degree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopeful) Psych major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English Lit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, man. But you're good at it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand what it's like to want  to leave a problem behind. That's  all most people are looking to do. (shrugs) Mainly, I listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where ya going? I've got a million  questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you Thursday... regular time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford goes inside. Skip nods, head spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford and Sofie are delivering newspapers in lovely fir light. Mumford has a canvas sack full of newspapers aroun his neck. At each house, he consults the list in his hand then hands Sofie a rolled-up paper, which she throws -- w varying success -- toward the front doors. The activity i tiring for her, but she's committed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so we get on this incredible steam  engine train that runs up into the  mountains... (she tosses a paper,  grunting) ...and this trip is everything it's  cracked up to be... an open car,  great views, the mountain air blowing  through. We're sitting there, married  for six years, and he says how he  likes it better when I put my hair  back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford hands her another paper, which she heaves with al her limited strength, missing the front porch badly. Mumf who can't get enough of watching her, doesn't notice at f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford snaps out of it. He goes up on the lawn and flips the paper deftly onto the porch. As they continue --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I'm going to make it  the whole way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... this makes me sound irrational,  which is probably right, but there  was something about him saying this --  it was maybe the millionth time he'd  told me about some preference of  his. Well, I was so... tired of it. (memories) Seems like my whole life someone's  been telling me... I'm just not  getting it right. Can we rest for a  second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans against the iron handrail on some front steps,  breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're purposely making me talk while  we do this... (Mumford nods) ...because you think this is good  for me... (nods again) ...and you're a sadistic bastard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...who thinks there's nothing really  wrong with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there's something wrong with  you, all right. Especially after  hearing that dream of yours, about  the Roto-Rooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs. They're playing with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was really bad, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll bet you can interpret the  whole thing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty obvious to a trained  professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie starts walking again, taking another newspaper from his sack. He points to the next house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate those dreams where everything  means something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie heaves the paper squarely onto the porch. She turns him with pride, but when she sees the way he looks at her she glances away, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that when you split up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that'd be a good story, but that  was just the beginning of the end.  We went on for another year or so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford hands her another paper and indicates the next ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whose route is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brady Peck's. Fourteen years old.  Lives next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the capitol for Boy's Nation.  Five days. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heaves another paper) I'm thinking a gal could make a good  living doing this. How hard could it  be squeezing out some fourteen year  old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you can expect me at 5:30  tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is legitimate therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therapy? Hell no, I just don't want  to do it alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON RAPID SERIES OF IMAGES on slick, glossy magazine pages: each change of image is punctuated by the AMPLIFIE SNAP of the page being turned, like a gunshot. We're SO C to the images we can't tell when the magazines change --  from Glamour to Vogue to Us to Mademoiselle to W to Vanit Fair. And it doesn't matter. Whether the images are ads o fashion spreads or celebrity candids, the look is the sam jaded, hip, disinterested, apathetic, either impossibly b or anorexic, but always severely beautiful. The PAGE TURN starts at a fevered pitch and becomes even more intense.  Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Nessa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The IMAGES CONTINUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she amazing? That is such a  wicked look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just chill for a second. Look at  this guy, it appears he's actually  dead... but gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is sitting next to Nessa on the couch. At their f is a mess of magazines. Nessa discards one and immediatel starts flipping through a new one beneath it. She is very agitated. Mumford stands up, walks over and sits in his c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? We're not done.  I just need to find the thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't want to have a session  today, it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to have the session. I thought  it would be cool if I could show you  some of the things that interest me.  But I guess you're not into it...  which we already knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it something that happened at  school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (petulant) These appointments were not my idea,  remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True. Should we stop them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of panic crosses Nessa's face, but she instantly h it, busily taking out cigarette and lighter, which she do use. Instead, she lies down on the couch, balancing the c magazine on her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you know what you're  talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This shrink school you went to...  did you hear about it on an  infomercial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford waits. Nessa refers to the magazine beneath her c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to live in the world these  people are in. No one ever says  anything in there, have you noticed?  So they're very cool. Like they're  all really deep. It's when people  start talking that everything goes  to shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nessa suddenly seems on the edge of tears, but beats it b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's this kid at school... Martin  Brockett. He has some gigantic idea  of himself that no one else shares.  You wouldn't believe the crap he  lays on me... Who appointed him my  spiritual leader? If he has everything  so figured out how come his best  friend is a .22 rifle? And why's he  spend all his time chasing after me?  Probably thinks I'm gonna give him a  hummer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that's what he wants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) No. I don't know what he wants. But  I know I don't like being watched.  Nobody's ever paid any attention to  what I did, and I liked it just fine.  Where does he get off telling me I  disrespect myself? (a beat) Fuck him. Look in a mirror, bozo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford crosses the street from his office. A huge bus wi "APPLEJACK TOURS" on the sides, is disgorging its passeng a large group of elderly JAPANESE WOMEN, all of whom file neatly into Lily's CafГ©. Lily stands on the sidewalk out greeting them merrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily continues her welcomes, but points out a hand-letter sign in her front window -- "Closed for Lunch. See you  tomorrow."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come through a few times each  year. (greeting one cheerily) Hello, Mrs. Saito, good to see you  again! (back to Mumford) It's a tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I supposed to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on your own today, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford's attention is suddenly drawn to something across the street. He glances thoughtfully at Lily for a moment, then back out there. WHAT HE SEES: Skip is once again zipping down the street his skateboard in the midst of traffic. He has not notice Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Skip!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip looks over, then immediately changes course toward t barely checking the surrounding traffic. He is extraordin skillful. When he gets to the curb, he pulls a snazzy boa flipping maneuver to dismount and come up on the sidewalk Some of the Japanese matrons react with delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip notices the tour members filing by, but is immediate distracted by the presence of Lily, who's a little excite to meet the local celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily, I want you to meet Skip. Skip,  Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pleasure to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) Yeah... me you, too... I was at your  house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs, with Doc... Yeah, it's  very nice... I heard your shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip can't believe what he just said. Neither can the oth two, actually. Mumford can't stop himself from laughing, he cuts it off fast. Lily blushes, but Skip's agitation h charmed her. Something's happening here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen you going by on your board,  but I didn't realize -- you're so  young... to be so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so rich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives him a look) ...so accomplished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may be young, but Doc can tell  you, I'm very immature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's making a joke and it represents quite a recovery. Th all relieved. Then there's an awkward silence. Skip watch the last of the tour enter the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, is this like a Japanese  restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better get in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lot of people all at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. They pre-order. There's a  choice of three entrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily gives him a careful look: Is he really interested?  There's something about him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meat loaf, turkey quesadillas, or  salad nicoise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salad nicoise? I love salad nicoise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giggling) You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She motions him in and starts to follow. Mumford makes a  "what about me?" sound. Lily, grinning, just points to th sign and leaves Mumford standing on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford turns to find Dr. Delbanco and Phyllis Sheeler, t shrinks Lionel had conferred with, standing nearby. It ta a moment for Mumford to remember Delbanco. Finally, shaki hands --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Delbanco. It's nice to see you  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you know Dr. Sheeler.  She's the other therapist here in  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her hand) Of course... I've heard great things  about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never got back to me. (Mumford doesn't  understand) ...I called to say we'd like to take  you out for a meal?... Kind of a  professional welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford makes a show of remembering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, please. What a gracious  thought. We must do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't I call you when I've got  my calendar in front of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other two nod in unison. Mumford considers, trapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town's upscale dining spot. Mumford, Delbanco and She are in a red leather booth. Sheeler listens with rapt,  admiring attention as Delbanco speaks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...annihilation anxieties engendered  by bad experiences with a depriving  mother... but no one can escape the  fear of death. It is, as Henry James  put it, "the worm at the core." Try  as we may to forget or ignore our  mortality, James said -- (theatrically) -- "the skull will grin in at the  banquet."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford nods appreciatively. (He really is an extraordina listener.) Delbanco catches his own vanity in Sheeler's  adoring gaze and becomes self-conscious --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've run on. Forgive me. We're here  to talk about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering) What Ernest means, I think, is we're  very interested in other  methodology... different kinds of  training. We're great believers in  learning from each other. I've learned  so much from Ern -- Dr. Delbanco...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And I from Phyllis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to a previous  thread) So... the University of Kentucky.  Who runs the program down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mentor was an amazing teacher  named Benton Mandlebaum. Died quite  tragically in the collapse of a  gazebo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've heard of him... a  disciple of Rothberg, wasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford's response, and all that follow, is calm and plea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible. I don't know about  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose your extended training was  at an institution in that area?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of institutions. My graduate  advisor believed we should experience  as many environments as possible --  prisons, clinics, half-way houses.  For a while I was chief therapist in  a shopping mall. Had a little spot  next to the yogurt place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting approach. What was his  name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy Fowler. Fantastic woman. She  passed last year in a train wreck.  Damned Amtrak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delbanco and Sheeler exchange a look. Sheeler adopts a  "casual" tone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trained in the east, myself --  Cornell -- and I don't care what  anyone says, there really are regional  differences. I found the state  certification exams out here quite  harrowing... Did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, very tough. But I guess  that's good... to keep out the quacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which examiner did you have? I  probably know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace Franklin... from Greensburg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark look comes over Sheeler's face for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a terrible thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agrees) I don't even know why hang-gliding  is considered a legitimate sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back on track) We're interested in any new therapies.  How would you characterize your  approach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My approach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... your particular approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have one really. Most of the  time I'm faking it. See, I think  there's not much that can be done  about most problems... they're too  complicated, too deep-rooted by the  time I hear about them. The most I  can do, usually, is look and listen  real closely, try to catch some  glimpse of the secret life everybody's  got. If I can get a sense of that,  well then, maybe... just maybe, I  can help them out a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford sits back, considering the couple across the tabl His gaze is so crystalline that, after a moment, they bec uncomfortable and steal a glance at each other. Finally -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Althea Brockett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- The argument had nothing to do  with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. I just want to know  what the argument was about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hates to say) I had ordered some books. "The 100  Greatest Books Ever Written."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. What are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, all the great writers --  Shakespeare, Charles Dickens, Moby  Dick... those people. Each is bound  in genuine premium leather with 22  carat gold accents. It's a magnificent  set -- and only $33.50 per volume.  Right away you get Great Expectations  for just $6.99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's irrelevant. It had nothing to  do with what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Althea is sitting on the couch facing Mumford. She has a  bulky knit cardigan sweater hugged tightly around her -- only sign that she's not completely calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We argued on Sunday. He went to work  on Monday and stayed in the city  during the week, like always. But on  Thursday, when he normally comes  home, he didn't. Didn't call either.  Not till Saturday afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have been concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's happened before. (a beat) I'm shocked by how little I'm feeling.  I can't understand it. (a real question --) I'll probably have a complete  depressoid collapse soon, won't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doubtful. What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he wasn't coming back. He  said it wasn't working for him any  more. That it hadn't "worked for  him" for quite a while... You know  what I regret the most? I'm sorry I  let him make the kids take his name.  He was an acquirer. (off Mumford's look) He liked to acquire things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks away. Althea realizes what he's thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that has something to do  with my problem? Ordering all those  things?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hadn't occurred to Mumford, but it's an interesting  thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Like I was on some kind of campaign  to out-acquire him... (excited now, playing  it out) ...If I was just an acquisition to  him, and he lost interest once he  had me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That can't be it. It's too simple.  And besides, I still like it. This  morning I ordered a marble turtle  cheese board from The Horchow  Collection. (an odd look) Can I tell you something just awful?  You know how people who are just  assholes will sometimes look at a  woman who's got problems and say,  "What she needs is a good shtupping!"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there may be something to that.  Jeremy didn't keep up his end -- Oh,  what difference does it make? (suddenly) Why do I feel elated? Am I in denial?  You know what it feels like?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances at her watch, then starts talking fast --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know my time's up, but I've got to  get this out while I've got hold of  it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no slowing down) -- When I was in high school, the  thing I wanted most, when I was stuck  in class, the thing I was always  desperately in pursuit of -- was a  hall pass. That's all I wanted. I  loved moving freely around the school  while everybody else was trapped in  there... And that's how I feel right  now... Like I have some giant, all- day hall pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is beaming, but suddenly becomes self-conscious. She  stands up abruptly, flushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My god, did it just get hot in here  or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes off the bulky sweater and bends to pick up her  purse. She is wearing a simple cotton dress that buttons the front and hugs her body. WE SEE for the first time wh all her other outfits have hidden: Althea has a terrific, voluptuous figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you next time. I'll probably be  a basket case by then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads toward the door to the waiting room. Mumford  indicates the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go out there if you like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting Mumford) "There's no shame in getting a little  therapy", right, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door to the waiting room, startling Henry  Follett, who jumps up from a chair out there, magazine st in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett is embarrassed to be discovered here. But that's  secondary to the impact Althea's current appearance -- se body framed in the doorway -- is having on him. She's bee customer in his store, but he's seeing her now as if for first time. All his libidinous buttons are being pushed.  Althea breezes by, oblivious to his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Follett. Have a good  session. Bye, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Follett continues to stare in the direction Althea ha gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is being escorted across the spectacular atrium b PANDA SECURITY AIDE. Her informal uniform, and all the ot details in the building, carry out the Panda design motif As they head down the main corridor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Doc!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks that way. In the distance, Skip is descendi from an upper level on his skateboard via a unique system ramps designed for that purpose alone. None of the hustli Panda Employees in the area take any particular notice of the sight. Skip meets Mumford and his escort at the bottom of the ra with a spectacular stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jennifer, I'll take him from  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Security Aide retreats as Skip (riding slowly alongsi leads Mumford into a side corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS. Skip and Mumford move through a maze of  hallways with progressively less foot traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never brought anyone down here  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm honored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc, there's something about what  you told me the other night I can't  get out of my head. It's driving me  batty -- (Mumford nods, waits) Why me? How did you know you could  trust me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're completely reliable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip is pleased. They approach a heavy steel door, the  entrance to Skip's Workshop. A VERY OLD SECURITY AIDE sit at the end of the intersecting hallway, watching this are Skip shouts down there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just me, Dino!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man nods, barely awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip, I've got a problem and I need  some advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want my advice? Far out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip puts his hand in a scanning device in the wall. Some lights blink and the heavy metal door pops open a few inc Skip has to put all his weight into opening the door. He  hesitates, suddenly concerned --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope nothing you're about to see  will shake your faith in me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford reassures him with a look. Skip pushes the door o far enough for them to enter, then pulls it closed behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford and Skip enter the large, windowless workspace. W at first appears chaotic is, in fact, carefully organized Many different disciplines interface here: THE BODY SECTION: The first thing one notices -- some  incredibly life-like, anatomically correct,  sculpture/mannequins -- both male and female. You half ex them to breathe. From there, a full wall of forms descend from store mannequins and skeletons all the way down to a huge variety of inflatable sex dolls. THE CYBER SECTION: A dizzying array of computers and scre some showing wire-form outlines of body parts in repeated motion. Above them, on a huge corkboard, hundreds of comp generated renderings of skin, eyes, limbs, sexual organs. THE BODY PARTS SECTION: Medical models of teeth, eyes, li limbs. Hundreds of porn store samples: plastic dildos, ru vaginas, sucking machines and sundry genitalia. THE FORM-CASTING SHOP: All the machinery you need to make rubber and acrylic forms of anything that can be computer designed. All these weird objects are set upon shiny, spotless, hig tech work surfaces. Skip watches Mumford move about in aw picking up the odd item.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty creepy, huh? Are you totally  disgusted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("no") Skip, you're a visionary. That can  be a burden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't seem a little...  perverse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a lot of lonely people in  the world. Somebody's gonna figure  this out someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not going to be me. I'm giving  it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all your fault. In the last 48  hours, I've completely lost interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip looks at Mumford, a wide grin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily... (gets it) ...Skip, that's great! You and Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she doesn't know about it yet.  Right now, of the two of us, I'm the  only one in love. But I'm very stoked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip settles in front of the Body Parts section, framed b an array of limbs and sex toys. There's an assembled pelv section with upper legs lying in the clutter behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc, how I can be of help to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip leans back against the table and accidentally hits a button. The pelvic section begins to hump, slowly and  sensually, in place. It's amazingly life-like, but it mak a mechanical WHIRRING SOUND. Skip fumbles to turn it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip gets the pelvis switched off and turns back to Mumfo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here for you, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip, you know that it's improper --  completely unethical -- for a licensed  psychologist to carry on a romantic  relationship with one of his patients?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes it does...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford sinks into silence. He begins to wander the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've fallen in love with one of  your patients?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford nods. Skip is desperate to say something useful.  Suddenly, he has an alarming thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc!... It's not me, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford understands and can't stop a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Skip, it's not you. But I like  you a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip is relieved. He has another thought and brightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc, what about this? You're not  really a licensed psychologist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford turns to meet Skip's gaze. Skip realizes the  ramifications of what he's just said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. I guess that doesn't help... I  see where you're going here. It's a  mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel is here with Delbanco and Sheeler. This time, Delb is behind his desk, Sheeler across the room on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you find it incredibly  convenient that everyone who could  possibly corroborate his story has  recently died some exotic death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're neither all recent nor exotic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're certainly dead. And yes,  personally, I find it a bit odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could happen. What about his state  certification exams? The records  seem to be in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel's derisive snort is so obnoxious, it's hard to bea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's easier than hacking your way  into a state computer and inserting  some numbers? For all you know he  never even took the exams!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know that it's all that  easy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, correct me if I'm wrong, but  it sounds to me like you've gone for  this guy's story hook, line and bull- twaddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do seem much more disposed toward  him than I understand, Ernest. Did I  miss something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Oh, for god's sake, Phyllis -- we  have no reason to doubt the man! Are  we listening to Lionel now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheeler jumps, so shocked is she by his outburst, and so  humiliated for Lionel to witness it. Fighting tears and t to maintain her dignity, she gathers up her things and wa to the door. Delbanco, immediately contrite, stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to  shout...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Dr. Delbanco, it is I who am  sorry. Sorry to have wasted your  time with such...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks into tears and rushes out of the office. Delba is left facing Lionel, who gives him exactly the look the doctor least wants to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is eating his lunch at the counter. He watches Li busily working the midday rush. She sees him grinning at  her, but doesn't say anything for a while. Finally, blush

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! He's a kid. I'm old enough  to be his... older sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford smiles, eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cook opens the front door to Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mumford. Please, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford comes in, reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Cook. I was wondering if  Sofie was around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you supposed to have a session?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's sort of spur of the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford follows Mr. Cook into the room. Mrs. Cook and Sof thirtyish brother, BEN, are in there, watching television Mrs. Cook keeps knitting; Ben stands to shake Mumford's h muting the TV with a remote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who's here. Have you met Sofie's  moth--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- We've met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And our son, Ben...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vigorously shakes  hands) This is a real honor, Doctor. Have a  seat, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford continues to stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually, I can't really... Do  you think I could see Sofie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I insist! I've been wanting to meet  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icy) Sofie's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford's surprised. Mr. Cook speaks with some pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her friend from the city came and  took her out to dinner. First time  in a long time she's been willing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We owe that to you. She's perked up  a lot since you started treating  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cook gives Ben a condescending look and keeps knitti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I think we need to  talk about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we have a right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We certainly do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it zipped, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben gives Mumford an exasperated look, but doesn't argue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there something we need to know,  Dr. Mumford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is conflicted, not sure what to share with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... yes, I guess I should tell  you. I don't think I'm going to be  able to treat Sofie anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cook and Ben exchange an alarmed glance. Mrs. Cook  actually cheers up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, some common sense...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I really don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very calm) Why don't you go to hell? It's all a  bunch of nonsense and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, I'm tellin' you, stop  this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive) You're telling me? That's rich...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up) I'd better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you see Sofie? I know the  treatment's working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks from Ben to Mr. Cook, who nods his agreemen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... you see, the problem is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the problem is you're a big fake.  You haven't got a clue what's wrong  with that girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks at Mrs. Cook and can't stifle a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. You're something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a hike, Dr. Quack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring her now) What is the problem, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford can't take his eyes off Mrs. Cook, even as he spe to Mr. Cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problem? I guess there is no  problem... Uh, this friend of Sofie's,  where'd he take her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's she -- Roxy. Used to work with  her. I think they went over to The  Lantern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) Oh, Roxy! Excellent. Roxy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cook looks at him sharply. She's heard what the othe two have not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford carries a large Fed-Ex box down a side street and into an alley. As he passes a secluded space created by t adjacent buildings, something catches his eye. MUMFORD'S MOVING POV: A young couple is embracing and tal intimately. As they separate, we can see that it is Nessa and Martin Brockett. Martin sees Mumford, but makes no si Nessa twists to see what Martin's looking at just as the  view is interrupted by a wall. Mumford walks on, mulling what he's seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a locked security screen at the alley entrance t the back room of the pharmacy, but the door inside is ope When a YOUNG PHARMACIST appears in there, Mumford raps on the metal screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett's private space is above and at the back of his  drugstore. When you sit at his desk and in front of it, a Follett and Mumford are doing now, you can see down into store through a floor-to-ceiling, one-way mirror. The Fed-Ex box sits on the desk between the two men, unop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a thought I had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I open it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford seems hesitant, but nods. Follett takes out an Ex knife and makes the first incision, but as he's about to on, Mumford suddenly reaches out and stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me just say something here... I  have no idea if this is going to  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly is it supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember when I asked you about  pornography --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I find it degrading. Maximum  gynecology and minimum turn-on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and you told me that. Still,  there's some kind of imagery that's  haunting you and, I think, getting  in your way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Which I don't necessarily agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you did come to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett reacts. It's true, even if he keeps forgetting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My guess is these images were burned  into your brain when you were young.  Maybe if we could nail down the exact  fantasies that are haunting you --  maybe you could get past them...  Anyway, I thought we could try an  experiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the box) And the experiment is in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford nods, but suddenly looks depressed, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? I think this was a  dumb idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to take hold of the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I just heard myself talking and I  realize I'm completely unqualified  to be doing this. Let's forget the  whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett grabs the box back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, what are you doing? I  want to know what's in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling on the box) There's absolutely no reason to think  this is going to have any impact on  you. I'm embarrassed to have --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett stands up and grabs the box, taking sole possessi Loud --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I agree with you that you don't  know what you're talking about. That's  what I've been saying all along. And  I can guarantee you that looking at  the Lost Ark or whatever you got in  here is not going to mean diddly to  me... (quieting down) ...but if you think I'm going to let  you walk out of here without seeing  what's in this box, you don't know  much about Henry A. Follett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford gives up. Follett gestures to ask whether it's sa to put the box on the desk; Mumford reassures him. Now, w much more anticipation and ceremony than before, Follett  carefully cuts open the package. THE CONTENTS OF THE BOX is revealed as Follett opens the  flaps. There is an inner, brown paper wrapping upon which has been set a low-rent catalogue: "METROPOLITAN COLLECTI Periodicals, Erotica, Adult Nostalgia." Follett lifts awa the wrapping -- There are perhaps a dozen men's magazines of the late fif and early sixties: Nugget, Adam, The Adam Reader, Swank,  Dude. Plus several cartoon collections: Sex to Sexty, Sta Humor. Plus trashy adult novels of the era, with provocat illustrations on the covers: Night Call Nurse, The Neighb Have No Curtains, Secretarial Sluts, etc. Finally, two vi tapes, both of Russ Meyer films: MUDHONEY and COMMON-LAW  CABIN. We stay CLOSE ON the contents of the box as Follett's han shuffle through it, rapidly flipping through the pages. V soft-core by today's standards, the common thread is clea voluptuous, heavy-breathing sirens in tight clothes (and of them) tempting muscular, he-man drifters or libidinous businessmen. A world of lusty secretaries, siren babysitt and frustrated, neglected wives. In other words, exactly erotic ambience of Follett's fantasies. SLOW TILT UP TO FOLLETT'S FACE. He is transported, mesmer galvanized. In fact, at this moment, as the MUSIC SWELLS, tear is rolling down his cheek. He dare not take his eyes from this Holy Grail to look up at Mumford. The only thin that could wreck his mood now, is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Follett --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett jumps, startled from his revery. As the Young  Pharmacist steps tentatively into the office, Follett jam everything back into the box as best he can and tries to  cover it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! What the hell is so important  I can't have five minutes --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Pharmacist is cowed and doesn't advance into th room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her, sir. You told me to get  you when she came to pick up her  prescription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes Follett a moment to understand, but when he does his whole manner changes. He dismisses the Young Pharmaci with a nod, then gives a quick, self-conscious glance to  Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, sorry, I'm going to have to... (indicates box) ...I really appreciate what you're  trying to... uh, I can't thank you  enough for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett heads for the door, pausing briefly at a mirror t check his appearance, pushing at his hair with his palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you on... whatever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries out. Mumford stands up to leave, but first loo down through the one-way mirror. WHAT HE SEES: Follett hurries up behind the prescription  counter, where Althea Brockett is waiting; once again she looks quite sexy. Follett brings her prescription up and  begins playfully flirting. Althea is responsive. Follett  motions Althea down the aisle, where it's more private. H comes out from behind the counter, ostensibly to show Alt something on the prescription bottle. Althea leans back  against some shelves in the same posture as the Landlady Follett's first fantasy. Mumford reacts, bemused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford and Sofie make their way slowly up the trail. Des her labored breathing, it's clear Sofie has made enormous progress since we first saw her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was in high school we used to  come up here and make out. I liked  to sit on the rock and watch the sun  go down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you come to the house the other  night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I had something to tell  you. But it turned out I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother said you were about to  fire me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one way to put it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet I know what changed your mind... (Mumford looks at her) ...My mother. She was so horrible,  you decided you couldn't desert me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought only action movies had  villains like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie gestures ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the cut-off, isn't it? (Mumford nods) I know why you were going to quit  seeing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford slows at this. Sofie heads off the trail into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie appears first, but she waits for Mumford before she steps tentatively onto the rock. Mumford takes firm hold her and leads her to a spot where she can securely settle herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel like a fake, an imposter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks up, sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as if maybe you don't know what  you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts a hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody feels that way sometimes...  like we're not who we're supposed to  be. But I have to tell you, Dr.  Mumford --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He winces at her formality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you've been a tremendous help to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tell you how much I admire  you. You have a wonderful way with  people. And you're very insightful.  I feel like you've seen me clearly...  I never used to admit what a horrible  person my mother was. You've made  that possible for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's... good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! And my ex-husband -- he never  accepted me for who I was, just like  Mother. The things you've said have  helped me understand what a dick he  is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shockingly honest, that's  what makes you great. I've never had  a man treat me this way. With you, I  feel really... listened to. (gives him a look) Can I tell you something? It's a  little embarrassing, but I feel very  unguarded with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks to this therapy, I now know  what I'm looking for. I need to find  a man like you. (laughs) Not one who's treating me, of course. (full of resolve) And I'm going to do it, dammit! You've  given me the confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
