dialogues.text: Mumford is in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie... that makes me very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nessa's on the couch, playing with her usual unlit cigare There's an uncharacteristic lightness to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I mean, Doc, the dude is seriously  deluded. I said that to him, I said,  "If you think I'm gonna do all that  shit for you, man, you are seriously  deluded."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't hide her  pleasure) He said -- "Which we already knew!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford laughs, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he want you to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First off, he tells me to stop smoking  cigarettes. I told him abso-fuckin'- lutely no. As you can see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up the cigarette as though it were her middle  finger, flipping the bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he says stop smoking dope. No  again. So then he says he doesn't  want me getting together with any  other guys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford doesn't have to see her face to know how much ple this gives her, despite her hard-ass cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What balls on this guy? What're  we... (too geeky for her) ...going steady? Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long pause) I said I'd consider it. Nobody owns  me. And the last thing was insane. I  don't know what's wrong with him...  No magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I can quit. We're  gonna try it together, like, you  know, AA or something. And I made  him give up his .22. No more sneaking  around the hills with his fucking  nut gun like some loony tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He agreed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yes) He's pitiful, Doc, a goddam puppy. I  don't know how much longer I can put  up with it. I already got two arms  and legs, I don't need another  appendage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a look at her watch and immediately lights her  cigarette as she stands up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops... gotta go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads toward the waiting room. Mumford gestures to  indicate the back door. She waves him off. He shakes his  head -- no one wants to use the back anymore. Nessa opens the door to the waiting room. Martin Brockett sitting there. He makes a gesture to Nessa to underline t fact that he is not reading any of the many magazines lyi around, then stands up. She goes into his arms like maybe she's the puppy. He beams and looks at Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling Nessa tighter) Did you straighten her out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nessa give him an affectionate punch in the side, then bl smoke in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insane! Didn't ja hear? My family  got five hundred times better. (turning Nessa) Let's go, Vanessa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nessa gives Mumford an embarrassed, "ain't he corny?" loo but as they go out the door, she's never looked happier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Mumford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is startled to find a man in a suit, GILROY, risi from the chair behind the door. He's got a briefcase and document in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see you there. Can I help  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Gilroy. I'm from the State  Certification Board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He proffers the document in his hand, but Mumford doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, it won't bite you.  Under civil code 1294.67b you are  entitled to be notified that your  status and certification are being  reviewed. This is the notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes the paper) Do you want to come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (already leaving) No thanks. Plenty of time for that  when we're a little further along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gilroy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilroy stops, outside door already open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brought this on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not at liberty to say. Sometimes  it's just routine, sometimes there's  been a complaint. We'll be in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out. Mumford considers the paper in his hands,  thoughts elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A PACKING CARTON half full of books. PULLING BAC and FLOATING OVER other boxes, half-packed with Mumford's personal belongings -- he doesn't have a lot. On the bed, open suitcase with a few clothes thrown in. We're STILL M across the room and out onto the porch, to REVEAL Mumford his chair, nursing a beer, looking up at the starry sky. Mumford HEARS THE SHOWER GO ON downstairs at Lily's. Then the MURMUR AND GIGGLE of a wet couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford smiles. He gets up and goes inside, closing the d behind him so as not to violate their privacy. He goes to the suitcase, takes out some clothes and begins putting t back in the dresser. Right now, he's not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE-UP of Ernest Delbanco. We can't tell where is at first. As he speaks, we PULL BACK to REVEAL him lyi on Mumford's couch -- a patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and when you said at lunch about  everybody having "a secret life",  something just snapped inside me. I  knew I could no longer continue my  relationship with Dr. Sheeler. It  was tearing me up inside. And I know  Phyllis wasn't getting what she needed  from it. What had started as a genuine  respect, I think, for each other's  professional abilities, and became,  over time, a personal attraction had  somehow... migrated into a rather  torrid sexual relationship...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the room, Mumford sits, chin in hand, displaying n reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I won't go into that today. Though,  if we should continue these sessions,  as I certainly hope we will, there  are some aspects of that I would  like to look at. God knows, I've  listened to enough people giving me  the juicy -- (catches himself) ...At any rate, I just wanted to  acknowledge the catalyzing effect  your comment had on me. I just hope  that it doesn't come roiling back  upon you like some dreadful undertow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This next is painful for Delbanco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... you see, when I broke it off  with Phyllis, she was naturally upset  and she became more determined than  ever to pursue certain -- how to put  it -- doubts she's been harboring...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of doubts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About you... your background and  your qualifications. I'm afraid  Phyllis somehow got you mixed up in  her fury with me, and actually took  the whole issue to the state board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford digests this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And please, for whatever small way I  may have encouraged this, accept my  apologies. (brightens) There is good news, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis has decided to leave town  and pursue her practice in the city.  Which leaves you the only psychologist  in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Sheeler is leaving Mumford? I'm  sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you can imagine, my own feelings  about this are mixed... Unlike, I  must say, those of my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford's head snaps up. He had no idea Delbanco was marr

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: We (CAMERA) are being pummelled by three SMALL TOWN TOUGH behind Old Man Sutter's gas station/diner in the Follett' fantasy town. [In BLACK & WHITE.] Beyond them, Old Ma Sutter's stacked YOUNG WIFE watches in horror from the  backdoor of the building. We DO NOT SEE The Newcomer yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Man Sutter's young bride had got  me in hot water all right, and now I  was bein' dealt the beating of my  life. If there'd just been two of  those bastards it would have been a  little closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Toughs winds up and delivers the coup de grace CUT TO BLACK, then FADE UP ON:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STILL IN SUBJECTIVE CAMERA as the concerned Landlady, cle foremost, stands away from us, having patted the unseen  Newcomer's face with a washcloth. Beyond her, near the ha open door, stands her Cheerleader Daughter, worriedly che on her thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Landlady was good at quite a few  things, but doctoring wasn't one of  them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO REVERSE and see the hero, who this time is actuall played by Henry Follett, appearing in his own fantasy for the first time. He's lying in bed, his face bruised in th manner of a fifties movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Lucky for me, one of the other  boarders, the broad who lived  downstairs in the front room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK AT THE DOOR, the Cheerleader hears someone coming an steps aside to make way for -- Althea Brockett, dressed n in a nurse's uniform so tight the buttons are straining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...was a nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Landlady and the Cheerleader retreat out the door, Althea the Nurse sways forward toward the bed bearing ban and a bowl of steaming water, a lascivious look of concer on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and she had ways to make you feel  better they didn't teach in nursing  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Althea the Nurse places a bandage over Follett's eyes,  BLACKING OUT THE SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford sits beaming at Henry Follett on the couch. Mumfo glance takes in the clock and he stands up, signalling th end of the session. Follett snaps out of his revery and g up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very happy for you, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford, surprisingly, takes Follett's hand and shakes it vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like we're making real progress  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too, Doc. And I can't tell you  what that package meant to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford stops him with a "don't mention it" gesture. Foll accepts and goes out the back door. Mumford is pleased so still wants to use that door. Mumford returns to his desk and begins reading some paper when he HEARS the entry door to the waiting room. Not  expecting anyone, he checks the clock, then goes to his o door and opens it. Sofie is standing there, very agitated, just about to kno She peers past him to see if he's alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you... Doctor. Can  I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie sits on the couch. Mumford sits in his chair, facin her. Her voice is as strained as her manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't met in this office since  that first time. This is how a real  professional and his client are  supposed to see each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might've been more appropriate if  we had followed a traditional approach  to the doctor-patient relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something wrong, Sofie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, something's very wrong, Dr.  Mumford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How intuitive! That must take years  of training right there. Maybe you  can guess what has upset me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford considers a long moment, several scenarios racing through his mind. Finally, carefully --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it something you've heard about  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it is not something I've heard  about you! It is someth-- (stops suddenly) Why? Is there something I should  have heard about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me what's on your  mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie suddenly finds it difficult to look into his eyes, looks around frenetically for a moment. Then, indicating couch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford gestures "of course." Sofie swings her legs up an lies on the couch so they can no longer see each other's  face. (It's the most vigorous movement she's yet shown us This seems to help Sofie a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... I'm going to come right  out and say this, because that's  what your shrink is for, right, so  you can tell him what's bothering  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tone still rough) First of all, I have been feeling  much better lately. I don't know if  the syndrome is over -- if it's just  run its course or something -- but I  feel a hundred per cent better than  when I first came to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given that, I'm obviously not going  to be judging things in the most  realistic way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't follow you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) I'm saying that since I'm doing so  much better -- which I attribute to  you -- I'm liable to misinterpret  some of my feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentative) Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is this -- I am not a blank  page. I did not just fall off the  turnip truck. Do you know what I  mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a little about psychology. I  took three different courses in  college. It's true, none of them  were above the two hundred level,  but I took them... And there was one  concept I remember very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transference!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and that is what I have got  right now. I have taken my feelings  of gratitude... and relief... and  transferred them onto... you. I have  taken all those warm, grateful  emotions and confused them with  feelings for you... So that now I am  under the delusion... (a deep breath) ...that I am in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford appears frozen in his chair. There is a heavy sil in the room. Sofie does not look back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you can understand why I  have some serious questions about  your methods. I mean, obviously it  becomes much more likely that I'm  going to have confusion about this  when your idea of treatment is to go  walking in the woods and up to make- outs-ville and do all these highly  romantic activities --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Sofie's voice cracks. She is starting to cry, b refuses to acknowledge it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- We had a paper route together,  for godssake! Do you understand how  I might be a little resentful? Knowing  that this so-called "love" I'm feeling  is totally bogus, and just a pathetic  case of... transference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford doesn't know what to say. He's on the rack. Final

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Then Sofie gets up, wiping at tears with the bac of her bare hand. Mumford jumps up to offer her a tissue, but she ignores it. She will not meet his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you ought to think about how  you're going to fix this. And when  you do... (suddenly losing her  will) ...please get back to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie turns to go out through the waiting room, but after step, she stops, pirouettes and goes out the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford comes up the street, lost in thought, and turns i the driveway toward his stairs. Ainge leaps over the fron yard fence. Mumford pets the dog distractedly, still movi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ainge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily rises up suddenly from where she's been working in t garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeps walking) Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford reluctantly stops. Lily comes up to the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you to be mad at Skip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yes) Skip and I wouldn't have got together  if it weren't for you. That's a big  deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismisses it) You would have met in some shower  eventually...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to give you something. Will  you let me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Lily, I don't need anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you do, you damn well do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't fight) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is, some advice -- do the  hard thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it? That's what you're giving  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean up the mess. No matter what it  takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford leans down to pet Ainge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it might take is... doing time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad. That's tough, I mean it.  I'm not unsympathetic. But Skip says  you're in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford straightens, looks at Lily and acknowledges it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford looks at Lily a long moment, then leans over the  fence and kisses her on the forehead. Ainge jumps back ov to her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell her tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford turns and continues toward his stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford comes in, drops his coat, gets a carton of orange juice out of the fridge and drinks directly from it.  Distracted, he picks up the remote from the kitchen count and switches on the TV, then opens his freezer and stares inside. UNSOLVED MYSTERIES comes on. The opening segment previews story about a couple who claim to have had a visitation f Gianni Versace, then one about a yacht that went down nea Venezuela. ROBERT STACK, in his characteristic fragmented delivery, intones the preview for the last story, accompa by appropriate footage:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A drug rehabilitation center in  the lonely southwestern desert...  run by reclusive monks... becomes  the point of departure in a mysterious  vanishing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOSE-UP of an IRS identification card featuring a pict of a younger Mumford, badly photographed in suit and tie. His name is not visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as an intrepid government  investigator disappears -- without a  trace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen, Mumford spins to look. DISSOLVE TO: LATER IN THE PROGRAM. Documentary shots of IRS Headquarte etc., are INTERCUT with hokey-looking re-enactments from  Mumford's life -- with a YOUNG ACTOR who looks vaguely li Mumford playing him. IN MUMFORD'S APARTMENT the telephone is RINGING. Clearly, it's not the first time. Mumford, watching the show inten lifts the headset an inch from the cradle and then hangs When it immediately RINGS AGAIN, Mumford takes it off the hook, cuts off the call, and buries the headset under a s cushion. ON THE SHOW: scenes of tax investigation -- in the show's version the IRS guys have drawn guns and are storming hou are interspersed with scenes of sordid drug-taking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...despite brilliant promise as a  fearless investigator... found himself  on a downward spiral of drug abuse  and dissolution...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUMFORD'S SISTER, the real thing, a plain, middle-aged We Virginia woman, appears in a "dramatic", badly-lit interv (As with all the interviewees, she is identified by a sup title.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we didn't talk much after our  folks died, but I know he felt his  life had taken a wrong turn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snapshot of some IRS-era party, happy revelers posing f a flash. Camera PUSHES IN on Mumford, smiling and high, h neck encircled by Gregory's arm. Candy is on the other si of Gregory. A shot of the Pennsylvania Turnpike as a State Police Cru zips by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His former undercover partner at the  IRS... is now a trooper with the  Pennsylvania State Police...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREGORY, in State Police uniform, with a sadistic glint i his eye, is interviewed by the roadside, cars whipping by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy was obsessed... didn't always  know where to draw the line... but I  would have trusted him with my wife --  er, my life -- (looks off camera,  laughing) -- What'd I say? Both, actually... (gets serious again) ...I can't say I was surprised,  though, when he disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragged telephoto shots of the Drug Rehab Center in the de low, innocuous adobe buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was this enigma... a courageous  public servant or a debauched  addict?... Either way, his last known  stop was here... isolated in the  Arizona desert... taken in by an  order of devoted monks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN AN ARIZONA TOWN, a monk with a clerical collar, BROTHE TIMOTHY, is loading groceries into the back of a pick-up. He's being ambush interviewed. He's polite, but not  cooperative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't talk about the people who've  been our guests... but I can tell  you this about our order -- we believe  everybody has the right to start  over... everybody deserves a second  chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shots of wind-swept desert, cactus, and dust-blown highwa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And perhaps... that is exactly the  chance the now-sober pilgrim took...  on a blustery November day... walking  away from the rehab center... never  to be heard from again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to know if he's alive. If  he is, I just hope he's happy and  his new life is... (not sure how to put  it) ...well, I hope he's found what he  was looking for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford, in his apartment, watches with real emotion. His sister's face DISSOLVES into a new snapshot of Mumfor dressed in an Orkin Exterminator uniform, as the MUSIC on the show comes up. A 1-800 telephone number appears acros the bottom of the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have any information about  this man or know anything about his  whereabouts, contact the Sheriff's  Department in Cochise County, Arizona,  or call this number...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford comes out to the rail and looks off over the town Mumford. WHAT HE SEES (or imagines he sees): all across the nights one window in every house is glowing blue with flickering light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING IN on the porch steps. Mumford runs into the shot. fact, he's run the whole way from his place and he's out breath. He takes the porch steps three at a time, rings t doorbell, and waits. Mrs. Cook peeks out, then opens the front door, an especi sour look on her face. She speaks through the screen door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look who's here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mrs. Cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just who is here, can you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I see Sofie, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you can not. I wouldn't know who  to say is calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cook glances inside at the as-yet-unseen Sofie, then hisses at Mumford --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could see right through you from  the start, you imposter. I know what  you're after. I knew it then and I  know it now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie appears behind her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think I'm after, Mrs.  Cook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie. It's so obvious... you're  after my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I gotta say, Mrs. Cook, you're  right about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Sofie and Mrs. Cook are set back for a moment. Mrs.  Cook recovers fastest --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll never happen! You're in big  trouble, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scary strong) Mother... go away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cook suddenly appears, takes Mrs. Cook by the arm and makes her vanish. Sofie and Mumford are left alone. She l at him through the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you saw the show...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which show was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of it. We were watching "ER"  until someone called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably got the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie comes outside. She doesn't get too close or look at him as she walks to the other end of the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what a betrayal this  is?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How violated I feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the only one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sofie turns sharply to look at him, ready to blow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel violated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me... all my other my patients.  I smelled tar and feathers on the  way over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford agrees. He watches her closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be irate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford immediately perks up. Sofie tries to correct --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am irate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing at the thread) But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But nothing... I'm mad as hell. This  is a terrible thing you've done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it! Please believe me, I know  that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford steps closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, there is one... mitigating factor  I want you to consider before you  write me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you think about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Depends. I'm in a bad  mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. More than I've ever loved  anyone or anything in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to spend the rest of my life  with you... but I'm not sure you  feel the same way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She regards him for several moments, her mind racing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sort of do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford feels joy. Now, finally, he takes her in his arms

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but first, you have to tell me  something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything... just ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mumford breaks into a huge grin, CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is at the defense table. Lionel is his lawyer. So Mr. Cook and Ben sit right behind the rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The defendant will rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford and Lionel stand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel sits down, squelched again. We see JUDGE OTTO for first time, a tough guy in his sixties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence Norman White, do you  understand how serious are the crimes  with which you have been charged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize how insidious it is  to invade the most private thoughts  and secret lives of unsuspecting  people?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE there's a pretty big turnout for this hearing.  Prominent among the onlookers: Lily and Skip, sitting  together; Nessa and Martin, holding hands; Dr. Delbanco a MRS. DELBANCO. Gilroy, from the State Certification Board sits with the PROSECUTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...People who have come to you with  the faith that you know what you're  doing... and that you are who you  say you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means absolutely nothing to me  that so many of your patients have  come forward with praise for you and  your therapeutic skills. You  understand that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follett is sitting in one of the back rows, apparently al But now he looks down the row. Althea is sitting down at end in a stylish suit, completely appropriate, but a size too small. She gives Follett a sidelong glance, then crosses her leg provocatively. Whatever fantasy they're currently enactin is working really well for both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. White, I am frustrated that the  criminal code in this state allows a  maximum sentence of only six months  and a maximum fine of only $2000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you're frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you disrespecting this court,  Mr. White?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. I was empathizing. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you can empathize with this --  Maximum fine. Three months in jail,  three months house arrest. Sentence  to begin immediately at the Orchard  Valley Correctional Facility. Case  closed. This court is adjourned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge slams down his gavel, stands up and stalks out. DEPUTY moves in to take custody of Mumford. Lionel stands and leans in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a country club. Don't worry  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your help, Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford turns to face the Cooks. Mr. Cook and Ben shake h hand like he's just won something. Lionel addresses them with his usual self-satisfaction --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have him out in half the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE PUSH IN on Mumford and Sofie, who embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got off easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you wait for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're only talking about six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course... I haven't got the energy  to get out of town that fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss. The Deputy takes Mumford's arm, and we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumford is alone in the backseat, handcuffed to a metal  restraint. A lone COUNTY CORRECTIONAL OFFICER is up front driving. There's a heavy security screen divider between  front and back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better make yourself comfortable. We  got a three hour drive here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the shrink, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you do therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride along in silence. At peace, Mumford watches the town go by. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you, Doc, the wife and I,  we got a little bit of a problem.  Would you mind if I just ran it by  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Correctional Officer watches Mumford in the rear view mirror, waiting hopefully. Mumford ponders the question a long time, then gives a "what the hell" shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State Correctional Sedan heads out of the business  district toward the highway, leaving the town of Mumford  behind. FADE OUT.
